Defines full or reduced stiffnessand mass matrices to be output from the Marc portion of SOL 600.This entry may be used to generate External Superelements using DMIG Matrices or an MSC Adams MNF File from the Marc portion of a SOL 600 analysis. SOL 600 only.(See the MNF600 and DMIGOUT Bulk Data entries.)  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MDMIOUT</td><td>ID</td><td>IDOF G3</td><td>G1 THRU</td><td>THRU G4</td><td>G2</td><td>ITYPE</td><td>NAME</td><td>IAUX</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>IDOF2 etc.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>IDOF3</td><td>G5</td><td>THRU</td><td>G6</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MDMIOUT</td><td>100</td><td>123456</td><td>1</td><td>THRU</td><td>5456</td><td>1</td><td>m343</td><td>1</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Subcase for which the reduced matrices will be output. ID must correlate to a SUBCASE Case Control ID,for example,if the case control contains SUBCASE 20, ID would be 20. (Integer; Default = 1)</td></tr><tr><td>IDOF, IDOF2</td><td>List of DOF's to be output (any or all of the integers 1-6 are acceptable). (Integer; Default = 123456)</td></tr><tr><td>G1,G3</td><td>Starting grid ID for reduced matrices. (Integer; Required; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>G2,G4</td><td>Ending grid ID for reduced matrices. (Integer; Required; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>ITYPE</td><td>Type of file to generate. (Integer; Default = 1)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td>1 DMIG Matrices</td></tr><tr><td>2 Adams MNF</td></tr><tr><td>NAME IAUX</td><td>Name of file containing the output (Character; no Default; limited to 8 characters, should be in lower case, the extension .dmi is added automatically)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ID of a MDMIAUX entry if the secondary run requires the use of file management entries or additional Executive Control statements such as the DOMAINSOLVER option for parallel processing. (Integer; Default = 0) A value of zero means that no auxiliary entries are required.</td></tr><tr><td>ISOL</td><td>Solution sequence to run using the DMIG matrices. To speed up the solution, use DOMAINSOLVER ACMS (PARTOP=DOF) for eigenvalues and set ISOL to the negative value of the solution sequence desired (-103,-1ll or -1l2). (Integer absolute value > 100; Default = O which means do not run any solution sequence using the DMIG's created by Marc in this execution)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The continuation line(s) are not required. 2. This entry corresponds to Marc's entry, SUPERELEM with a value of 1 in the second line 4th field and produces DMIG's or an MDF file for the initial geometry prior to any nonlinear iterations. 3. DMIG output will be in jid.marc_dmigst_0001. 4. The reduced matrices may be used in the Nastran analysis for eigenvalue extraction or any other purpose by invoking the CONTINUE $_{,=5}$ option on the SOL 600 entry. 5. If the SOL 60o CONTINUE options is invoked, case control commands and a bulk data entry include statements to receive the matrices willbe automatically added to the original input data file. A second Nastran execution willbe spawned from the original Nastran execution after completion of the Marc execution. 6. ID must be 106 or 129 in the Executive Control statement, SOL 600,ID. 7. Only one MDMIOUT entry should be entered per run.If more are entered, only the first will be used. 8. MNF controls for other solution sequences are ignored for SOL 600. 9.For the case where DMIG's are generated and a continuation option is used, the folowing Bulk Data parameters are usually required in addition to the MDMIOUT entry: \$2345678x234567890123456x34567890123456 param marcfile nastb.rc parammarcfill m3356 10. For a more general form of the DMIG output, see Bulk Data entry, DMIGOUT.

(Integer, Default=NPX)</td></tr><tr><td>NPZ</td><td>The number of cubes in the z-direction. (Integer, Default=NPX)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The grid-points of the mesh are generated at following locations: Type $\approxeq$ ADAPT: (x,y,z)=(XREF+i\*DXEL,YREF $^+$ j\*DYEL, ZREF+k\*DZEL) Grid-points and elements located a certain distance outside the coupling surface willnot be created. This saves memory and CPU time. When (XREF, YREF, ZREF) are outside the coupling surface, no grid-point will be created at this location, but the mesh will be shifted appropriately. Type $\mathbf{\sigma}=$ BOX: $\mathrm{(x,y,z)=(X0+i^{*}D X E L,Y0+j^{*}D Y E L,Z0+k^{*}D Z E L)}$ Nodes and Elements willalways be created, even if the MESH is referenced from the MESHID of a COUPLE entry. One of the following input combinations is required: TYPE $\left.,=\right.$ ADAPT a． (DXEL,DYEL,DZEL) or b.1 c. (DX, DY, DZ) and (NX, NY, NZ) →DXEL $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ DX/NX ; DYEL $\v{x}_{1}=$ DY/NY ；DZEL $\v{r}_{\mathbf{\lambda}}=$ DZ/NZ TYPE $\v{x}_{1}=$ BOX a. (DXEL, DYEL, DZEL) and (NX, NY, NZ) or b. (DX, DY, DZ) and (NX, NY, NZ) →DXEL $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ DX/NX ;DYEL $\v{x}_{1}=$ DY/NY ；DZEL $\v{a}_{\v{r}}=$ DZ/NZ  

2. When the starting grid point and/or element number is left blank,then the default start number for the elements and grid-points is equal to the maximum number used $+1$ . For simulations with multiple coupling surfaces two methods of treating transport between the Euler meshes are available. One method supports meshes of TYP $\mathrm{\ddot{E}=A I}$ DAPT, but does not allow the specification of starting element or starting grid-point number.  

3.The PID should refer toan existing property id, which can handle the property type given by PROP.  

4. To avoid that the Euler mesh willbe resized every time-step,the functions defined by TID-X, TID Y, TID-Z must describe a step-function', like in this example:  

i. TABLED1,1.,+ ii. $^{+,0.0,1.0,,,0.0,+}$ ii. $+,1.\mathrm{E}\substack{-3,1.0,,},0.7\$ iv. $+,1.\mathrm{E}\substack{-3,1.1,,,},\ ,+$ V. $+,2.\mathrm{E}\substack{-3,1.1,,},\hphantom{+}, $ vi.+,2.E-3,1.2  

Which specifies following function:  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/d39f294e-c3a1-40ea-9210-2d9b70ddcd07/cf05c10ca84d55aed405ff0ee200964c96fdd5860d91a3278942b411aafaf527.jpg)  

5.Care must be taken when refining the Euler mesh. To avoid instabilities,it is advised to stay withir the following guidelines:  

a. Each refining step, use a scale factor larger than 0.5   
b. Allow the solution to become smooth again after each refining step. For airbag simulations, use an interval larger than $5^{\star}$ diameter_airbag/soundspeed  

6. Resizing is not available for the Multi-material solver.  

7. In most cases METHOD $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ ALL is the preferred method. Using METHOD $\mathbf{\sigma}=\mathbf{\sigma}$ MATERIAL may be helpful in case of instabilities due to presence of void regions.  

8. SUBMESH glues a fine mesh into a coarse mesh and uses the same gluing functionality as PARAM, GRADEDMESH. If the fine mesh is completely contained inside the coarse mesh no restrictions apply. Then to avoid any restrictions the grid points of the fine mesh are slightly displaced. But if parts of the fine mesh are outside the coarse mesh a restriction applies. In that case an Euler element of the coarse mesh has to be fully active or fully inactive. This means that the coarse element should not intersect elements of the fine mesh or it should be fully covered by the fine elements. Fine elements are not allowed to cover any part of the coarse elements.In practice, this means that the fine mesh has to fit nicely in the coarse mesh.For details refer to the section "Graded meshes" in the MSC Nastran Explicit Nonlinear User's Manual.  

When running on one cpu the elements of the Euler mesh and the submesh willbe put into one euler archve.But when running with multiple cpus, the mesh and sub mesh willbe put in different euler archives. To distinguish the archives,the name_FVX is added to the Euler archive names.Here X is the MESH-ID MID.The Euler archive of the mesh and the submesh can be read simultaneously into Patran.  

9.A biased mesh has nonconstant element sizes in selected directories. Neighbor element size can have a constant ratio or have identical size. In literature, this type of mesh is also referred to as a nonuniform mesh or a locally refined mesh.  

10.A block mesh consists of a number of planes inallthreedirections.Fora nonbiased mesh,these planes are at fixed distance from each other. In a biased mesh, the distance between subsequent planes can differ. The varying element size is determined by:  

a. IBIDX   
b. GROWX   
C. The constant step size specified by X0, NX, DX.  

Here, IBIDX overrules GROWX and GROWX overrules the X0, NX DX specification. Likewise, for the other directions. The locations of the planes are written out in the OUT file.Intersecting an x-plane with a y-plane and z-plane will give a grid point. By carrying out all intersections, the grid points are constructed.  

11.Defining the CID alows for positioning the mesh box arbitrarily in space. When active,the following restrictions apply:  

MESH,ADAPT cannot be used $\mathbf{\alpha}_{\perp}$ The use of single material Euler with strength elements is not supported  

12. Setting NELCUBE, NBX, NBY, NBZ allow to divide the Euler mesh into a number of cubes. By settingNELCUBE equal to 2000, optimal use is made of memory caching during Euler computation. This can give a speedup of 1.5. If NBX is defined, also NBY and NBZ need to be defined. Defining NBX overrules the definition of NELCUBE.  

When using multiple Euler cubes the BARRIER and FLOW definitions only support geometric conditions like boundary face direction and square definition.  

13. There are several ways to distribute cubes across processors. Some ways may lead to bad load balancing.To avoid this it is possible to control the way Euler cubes are distributed across processors by defining PROCDIR.  

When option PROCDIR $\v{x}=$ USER, the values for NBX, NBY, and NBZ must be such that NBX is equal or a multiple of NPX, NBY is equal or a multiple of NPY and NBZ is equal or a multiple of NPZ. Also for this option, NPX\*NPY\*NPZ must be equal to the number of processors used in the cluster.  

For option PROCDIR $\v{x}=$ SIMPLE, the values NBX, NBY, and NBZ on DYPARAM,EULERCB must be such that $\mathrm{NBX^{*}N B Y^{*}N B Z}$ is equal or a multiple of the number of processors used. For instance, if the number of processors in the cluster is 4, NBX\*NBY\*NBZ must be equal to either 4 or 8 or 12, etc. Otherwise, the calculation will terminate prematurely with an error message.  

When using these options the Barrier and FLOW definitions only support geometric conditions like boundary face direction and a square definition  

14.Todetermineasuitablesizefor the static output box,the simulation can be run first without the fields XOBX, YOBX, ZOBX, DXBX, DYBX, and DZBX set. In the ,OUT file each summary of adaptive meshing gives the smallest box surrounding alladaptive elements so far.The last summary then yields the dimension of the static output box. To accommodate for elements that are not completely inside the box, the actual static output box is automatically extended a little. The actual dimensions are written in the out file after the first adaptive meshing summary. Is not needed to set the XREF,YREF, and ZREF option. If they are set the static output box willbe compatible with the defined reference point.  

## Defines External Superelement DMIG Input for SOL 600 Residual Analyses  

Superelement DMIG matrices are created by Nastran and used when Marc is spawned from Nastran, SOL 600 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>５</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MESUPER</td><td>ID</td><td></td><td></td><td>Fname</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MESUPER</td><td>1</td><td>super1.pch</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>MESUPER</td><td>2</td><td>super2.pch</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td> Superelement ID. (Integer; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>Fname</td><td>Filename containing external superelement data from the creation run (using Case Control EXTSEOUT (ASMBULK, DMIGPCH,EXTID=ID) (Character; no Default). Left justify in field, see Remark 8.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Enter as many MESUPER lines as necessary to define all external superelements.   
2. This entry can presently only be used with SOL 600,106, SOL 600,101, SOL 600,nlstatic,or SOL 600,sestatic.External Superelements are not presently available for other types of SOL 60O analyses such as nonlinear (or linear) transient dynamics, eigenvalue analysis or buckling.   
3. Fname is limited to 56 characters.   
4.Include entries with the same Fname must be specified as include files in the Nastran input file. The include specifications must appear at the end of the Bulk Data portion of the file.   
5. External superelement creation runs should use the Case Control command: EXTSEOUT(ASMBULK,DMIGPCH,EXTID $\mathsf{\Pi}=\mathrm{N}$ ） where N is the external superelement ID number. All creation runs must have the same number of subcases and use the same subcase IDs.   
6. The SOL 60O residual input file must have the same number of subcases and subcase numbers as the creation runs.   
7. This entry acts like an element, in other words it is not controlled by a case control command. It is always active if entered.   
8.The MESUPER entries should normally be coded in smallfixed field format. If coded in small format free field, Fname is limited to 8 characters.If coded in large format free field, Fname is limited to 16 characters. The filename may be extended to a continuation line.Allfilenames should be entered in lower case. Nastran will convert to upper case, and the SOL 60O translator willreconvert to lower case. The creation runs should also use lower case for all external superelement punch filenames for case-sensitive computer systems.   
9. If there are no elements in the residual (that is, allelements are in the external superelements, PARAM,MARCND99,-1 is required to output the displacements in the Marc .out file regardless of the specified Case Control request.   
10.The ASMBULK option in the creation runs is required for SOL 6O0 when outr options are specified. It is recommended whether or not outr options are specified.All.asm files (created by the ASMBULK option) for all external superelements should be included in the Bulk Data before any punch files (produced using the DMIGPCH option). See the following input file examples.   
11. At present, an OP2 with results datablocks only can be produced by a SOL 600 External Superelement residual execution. OP2 files which combine geometry and results datablocks cannot be produced. Other outr options such as xdb,fO6 and punch are also not available for SOL 600 External Superelement residual runs.   
12.For the External Superelement Initial run(s)to generate punch and asm files, no Case Control output requests should be made and the following DMAP should be inserted in the Executive Control in order to prevent extra information (which willcause an error) for being inserted into the punch file: compile extout alter 'sdr2' \$  

delete /iugl,... S alter 'sdr2’ （2）\$ delete /igulo,.., \$  

13.If data exists after ENDDATA, including any characters on the ENDDATA line, after the word ENDDATA in the creation run input, this data must be removed.  

Typical File Setup for External Superelement Creation Run for SOL 600 (same as for other solutio1 sequences)  

SOL 101   
compile extout   
alter 'sdr2' $\$5$   
delete /iugl,,., \$   
alter 'sdr2'(2) \$   
delete /iuglo,.., \$   
CEND

asetl,123456,840,thru,848   
CORD2R,1001,1002,, ，,1.0   
(rest of file same as any other Nastran run)

(Real; Default means that the free surface is located at an infinitely large positive value of XFS.)</td></tr><tr><td>RHO</td><td>Density of the fluid (Real).</td></tr><tr><td>ELIST1</td><td>Identification number of an ELIST entry that lists the IDs of two-dimensional elements that can be wetted on one side by the fluid. Only those elements connected to at least one grid point below ZFS are wetted by the fluid. See Remarks 3. and 5. (Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>ELIST2</td><td>Identification number of an ELIST entry that lists the IDs of two-dimensional elements that can be wetted on both sides by the fluid. Only those elements connected to at least one grid point below ZFS are wetted by the fluid. (Integer ≥ 0; ELIST1 + ELIST2 > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>PLANE1, PLANE2</td><td>Planes of symmetry, antisymmetry, or no symmetry. “S" means that plane 1, which is the plane containing the X and X3 axes of CID, is a plane of symmetry. “A" means that plane 1 is a plane of antisymmetry. “N" means that it is neither. See Remark 5.</td></tr><tr><td>RMAX</td><td>Plane 2 uses “S",“A", or“N"for the X and X plane. (Character: “S",“A",or “N") Characteristic length. Interactions between elements with separation that is greater than RMAX will be neglected. (Real > 0.0; Default = 1.0E 10)</td></tr><tr><td>FMEXACT</td><td>Exact integration is used if the distance between two elements is less than FMEXACT times the square root of the area of the larger element. Otherwise, center point integration is used by default. (Real; Default = 1.0E 15)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The MFLUID entry must be selected with the Case Control command MFLUID $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ SID. 2. Several MFLUID entries corresponding to different fluid volumes can be used simultaneously.   
3.The wetted side of an element in ELIST1 is determined by the presence or absence of a minus sign preceding the element's ID on the ELIST entry.A minus sign indicates that the fluid is on the side opposite to the element's positive normal, as determined by applying the right-hand rule to the sequence of its corner points.The same element can appear on two ELIST entries, indicating that it forms a barrier between the unconnected fluids.   
4.The fluid volume may be finite (interior) or infinite (exterior). The volume may be bounded by a free surface and one or two planes of structural symmetry. If structural symmetry is used, the structure must have the symmetric or antisymmetric boundary corresponding to the selection in fields 8 and9.Interiorfluids must have ELISTl data andafree surface or plane ofantisymmetry.   
5. The planes of symmetry and/or antisymmetry defined in fields 8 and 9 must be planes of symmetry for the entire analysis. The user may apply appropriate structural boundary conditions at all grid points lying in these planes.   
6. The current list of elements that may be placed in ELIST1 and ELIST2 include CTRIA3, CQUAD4, CTRIAR, and CQUADR. 7. The continuation entry is optional. 8.If there is ELIST1 data and no freesurface nor plane of antisymmetry, the program assumes a special form of external fluid. These special external fluids must have a CID (field 3) such that the origin of the fluid coordinate system is near the center of the enclosed volume, since the singularity for volume change willbe placed at the origin. Special external fluids are supported only in SOLs 103 and 107 through 112.If used in conventional solution sequences, System Fatal Messge 3001 results for file 205.   
9. See PARAM,VMOPT in “Parameters"on page 1409. VMOPT controls when the virtual mas is included in the mass matrix.   
10.If any MFLUID entry is changed oradded on restart then a complete re-analysis may be performed. Therefore, MFLUID entry changes or additions are not recommended on restart.   
11. A tolerance is computed for each wetted element, with the value of $0.01\sqrt{2\mathrm{A}}$ ,where A is the area of the element. If any grid point connected to the element lies within TOL below the free surface it is moved to the free surface.   
12.Any element that has all grids on or above the free surface, after the grid points are moved by the procedures given in Remark 11. is removed from the ELIST. It is not included in the VM efects, and will produce no pressure output.  

This entry is used to add soft springs to ground at selected grids to stabilize the structure in a nonlinear analysis. It is most often used with contact to stabilize freefree bodies before they come into contact. The spring rates selected should be stiffenough to alow matrix decomposition but weak enough so they are not significant once fullcontact is achieved. Values on the order of 1.0E-6 to 1.OE-4 times the average main diagonal terms in the stiffness matrix for the grids selected are recommended.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>MGRSPR</td><td>ID1</td><td>THRU</td><td>ID2</td><td>IDIR</td><td>K</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MGRSPR</td><td>100</td><td>THRU</td><td>200</td><td>123</td><td>10.0</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>500</td><td>THRU</td><td>520</td><td>123456</td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID1</td><td> Starting grid ID. (Integer; Required; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>THRU</td><td>Enter the character string THRU if more than one grid is desired.</td></tr><tr><td>ID2</td><td>Ending grid ID of the range. (Integer; or blank. If blank; ID2=ID1)</td></tr><tr><td>IDIR</td><td>Directions that the spring(s) will be added in, any unique combination of the integers 1 through 6 with no embedded blanks. (Integer; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>K</td><td>Spring rate. (Real; Required)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. If springs are to be added to all grids, PARAM,MRSPRING may be used instead of this entry.   
2. Do not use PARAM,MRSPRING and this entry in the same model.   
3.Grids that do not exist in the range IDl to ID2 willautomatically not have springs in the Marc input.  

This option is used to enter initial (stress free)temperatures calculated from a previous heat transfer analysis and saved on a tl6 or t19 file. (MCHSTAT is used to define the temperatures that cause thermal strains). This entry may also be used to initialize other state variables if required.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MINSTAT</td><td>IDV</td><td>IOPT</td><td></td><td>INCR</td><td></td><td>IFORM</td><td>IPRT</td><td>NPST</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>“FILE”</td><td>Name</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>“ELEM”</td><td>ELE1</td><td></td><td>ELE2</td><td>INT1</td><td>INT2</td><td>LAY1</td><td>LAY2</td><td>VAL</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>“STATE”</td><td>NS</td><td></td><td>IS1</td><td>IS2</td><td>IS3</td><td>IS4</td><td>IS5</td><td>IS6</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>IS7</td><td></td><td>IS8</td><td>IS9</td><td>etc.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MINSTAT</td><td>1</td><td>3</td><td></td><td>1</td><td></td><td>0</td><td></td><td>9</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>FILE</td><td colspan="3">initial_state_example</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>IDV</td><td>State variable identifier(l=temperature). (Integer; Default = 1) (2,1) If more than one state variable is required, enter -1.</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">IOPT</td><td>Option of how to enter the data. (Integer; Default = 3) (2,2)</td></tr><tr><td>1 Use the“ELEM" continuation line for as many elements as necessary</td></tr><tr><td>2 Enter the data using user subroutine INITSV</td></tr><tr><td>3 Read the data from a tl6 or tl9 file (see IFORM)</td></tr><tr><td>INCR</td><td>Increment number on tl6 or t19 file defining the new state values if IOPT=3. (Integer; no Default) (2,5)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="3">IFORM</td><td>Designates whether a binary (tl6) or formatted (t19) post file is used if IOPT=3. (Integer;</td></tr><tr><td>Default = 0) (2,7) 0 Use binary (tl6) file</td></tr><tr><td>1 Use formatted (t19) file</td></tr><tr><td>IPRT</td><td>Enter a value of 1 to suppress printing of state variable values defined in user subroutine</td></tr><tr><td>NPST</td><td>INITSV (only applicable if IOPT=2). (Integer; Default = 0） (2,8) Post Code ID to be read into this state variable.(Integer; Default = 9 [temperature]) (2,9)</td></tr><tr><td>FILE</td><td>See MARCOUT for a list of the post codes. Enter the character string FILE if IOPT=3. (Character; no Default; Required if IOPT=3)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>NAME</td><td>Enter the file name without the extension (.marc.tl6 or .marc.tl9). (Character; no Default) The file name must be entirely in lower case for case-sensitive computer systems and is limited to 56 characters. This file must be in the same directory as the Nastran input file.</td></tr><tr><td>ELEM</td><td>Enter the character string ELEM to start a list of elements and associated values if IOPT=1. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>ELE1</td><td>First element with value VAL. (Integer; no Default; Required) (3,1)</td></tr><tr><td>ELE2</td><td>Last element with value VAL. (Integer; Default = ELE1） (3,2)</td></tr><tr><td>INT1</td><td>First integration point with value VAL. (Integer; no Default; Required) (3,3)</td></tr><tr><td>INT2</td><td> Last integration point with value VAL. (Integer; Default = INT1) (3,4)</td></tr><tr><td>LAY1</td><td> First cross-section layer with value VAL. (Integer; no Default; Required) (3,5)</td></tr><tr><td>LAY2</td><td>Last cross-section layer with value VAL. (Integer; Default = LAY1） (3,6)</td></tr><tr><td>VAL</td><td>New state value for these elements. (Real; no Default; Required) (4,1)</td></tr><tr><td>STATE</td><td>Enter the character string STATE to start a list of state variables. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>NS</td><td> Number of state variables to be defined. (Integer; no Default; limited to 16 maximum)</td></tr><tr><td>ISi</td><td>State variable post codes. (Integer; no Default) (9,i) See MARCOUT entry for applicable post codes.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1.Only one MINSTAT entry may be entered in the input. Ifadditional entries are found, the first will be used.   
2. This entry maps to Marc's INITIAL STATE entry   
3. (i,j) refer to Marc's INITIAL STATE (data block, field)   
4. MINSTAT (and/or MCHSTAT)cannot be the only applied“loads".At least one standard load such as FORCE, PLOAD4 or a standard TEMP entry must be entered with a LOAD Case Control command that references the standard load(s).If there are no standard loads, please enter a dummy load with a very small magnitude and a LOAD Case Control command to reference it.  

Defines an island of connected elements that willbe completely removed if the number of elements within the island becomes smaller than a specified value in SOL 600 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>５</td><td>6</td><td>7 8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MISLAND</td><td>NELEM</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MISLAND</td><td>20</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>NELEM</td><td>Number of elements to use as a limit for element deactivation. If the number of elements in an island is less than or equal to this number, all elements in this island are deactivated. (Integer; no Default; Required field)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1.If this entry is made in the model, it subdivides the entire mesh into islands of connected regions.If the number of elements in a particular island is lessthan or equal to the specified value, all elements of this island are deactivated. This check is performed after element deactivation has taken place where the deactivation can be due to model input options, deactivation user subroutines,or through material damage or failure. Two elements are considered connected if they share a node for line elements,an edge for 2-D elements, or a face for 3-D solid elements.This option is useful for cases where unconnected elements or regions of elements might exist after the neighboring elements have been deactivated. There is no check performed to see if the island to be deactivated has enough boundary conditions. Only the number of elements in the island is used for determining if the elements should be deactivated.  

2. Only one MISLAND entry should be placed in the input. If more than one is entered, the first will be used.  

Consitituents of “Composite” Material on Original and Potentionally Damaged State - SOL 600  

Defines consitituents of“composite"material on original and potentionally damaged state. Used in SOL 600 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MIXTURE</td><td>MID</td><td>ITYPE</td><td>IALPH</td><td>ISET</td><td>M1</td><td>FRACT1</td><td>M2</td><td>FRACT2</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>M3</td><td>FRACT3</td><td>M4</td><td>FRACT4</td><td>M5</td><td>FRACT5</td><td>etc.</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MIXTURE 120</td><td>3</td><td>1</td><td>200</td><td>10</td><td>.2</td><td>20</td><td>.2</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>30</td><td>.2</td><td>40</td><td>.2</td><td>50</td><td>.2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Material ID (Integer; no Default, required field)</td></tr><tr><td>ITYPE</td><td>Mixture rule (Integer; Default = 1) 1</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4"></td><td>Weighted average of material properties based upon volume fraction.</td></tr><tr><td>2 Weighted average of Hooke's law based upon volume fraction</td></tr><tr><td>3 Weighted average of nonlinear stress strain curve based on volume fraction</td></tr><tr><td>Flag controlling averaging procedure for thermal expansion (Integer; Default = 1)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td>1 Weighted average based upon volume fraction</td></tr><tr><td>2 Not currently available</td></tr><tr><td>ISET Mi</td><td>ID ofa SET3 containing the all the elements making up this material (Integer; no Default; Required)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Identification of a previously defined material, defined on a MATxxx entry (for example the MID on a MAT1 entry) (Integer; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>FRACTi</td><td>Fraction for the ith component (see ITYPE). The sum of all FRACTi must add to 1.0 (Real; no Default)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Enter as many Mi, FRACTi components as desired. Each may have different properties,and failure criteria. 2. Fields 2-4 of each continuation entry are required, fields 5-9 may be left blank.  

3. This option alows one to create a new material comprised of a number of other materials. The material behavior is based upon a“mixture" of the individual components using a mixture rule. Several of these mixture rules are only appropriate for linear elastic materials but also allow for temperature dependent material properties. The most sophisticated model $\mathrm{(ITYPE{=}}3^{\cdot}$ ） allows for the mixture of materials which undergo elastic-plastic behavior.  

4. If void ratio or porosity is defined, it applied to all components in a uniform manner.  

5. ITYPE 1 and 2 only support linear elastic material.  

6. ITYPE 3 is not available using updated Lagrange - use PARAM,MARCPLAS,1 or PARAM,MARCPLAS,2 if any of the component materials have plasticity. The mixture will be limited to small strains, but large displacement, large rotation and follower forces and follower pressures can be included.  

7. ITYPE 3 may not include the following material laws in any of the components.  

Thermo-pore   
$\cdot$ Gurson damage   
Simplified damage models 9 and 10 Gasket material Shape memory material Soils User defined generalized stress strain ORNL Rigid-Plastic Grain size effects Rubber material (mooney, ogden, foam, gent, arruda-boyce) Cohesive   
8. Rebar elements and shell elements with offsets or non-composites with different properties for bending vs membrane (which use the Marc PSHELL option) may not be used for mixtures.   
9. Within a layer, if the components are orthotropic or anisotropic, the preferred directions must be aligned.   
10. The material identification number must be unique for all COHESIV, MAT1, MAT2, MAT3, MAT8, MATDIGI, MATG, MATHE, MATHP, MATNLE, MATORT, MATPE1,MATSMA, MATUSR, MCOHE, MIXTURE, and MATD\* entries.  

Provides a table of Mach numbers $\mathrm{(m)}$ and reduced frequencies (k) for aerodynamic matrix calculation.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MKAERO1</td><td>ml</td><td>m2</td><td>m3</td><td>m4</td><td>m5</td><td>m6</td><td>m7</td><td>m8</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>k1</td><td>k2</td><td>k3</td><td>k4</td><td>k5</td><td>k6</td><td>k7</td><td>k8</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MKAERO1</td><td>.1 .7</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>.3</td><td>.6</td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>mi</td><td>List of from 1 to 8 Mach numbers. (Real ≥ 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>kj </td><td>List of from 1 to 8 reduced frequencies. (Real > 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Blank fields end the list, and thus cannot be used for 0.0.   
2. All combinations of (mi, kj) will be used.   
3. The continuation entry is required.   
4. Multiple MKAERO1 entries are permitted.   
5.For the lifting surface theories (Doublet-Lattice and Mach Box),the maximum value of kj should be less than one quarter of the number of boxes on a representative chord (i.e., $\mathrm{MAX}(\mathrm{kj})<\overline{{\mathbf{C}}}/4\Delta\mathbf{x}$ where $\bar{\mathrm{{C}}}$ is the reference chord and $\Delta x$ is a typical box chord length).   
6. In SOL 146, the program selects only one value of mi to use in computing the dynamic response solution and, by default, the lowest value is selected. The PARAM,MACH,m entry may be specified to select a different value. If PARAM,MACH $\mathbf{\Omega}_{\mathrm{m}}$ is specified, then the value of mi closest to m will be selected.   
7.The verylow nonzero value ofkj required for aeroelastic divergence analysis of restrained vehicles with the $\mathrm{K}_{-}$ and KE-methods of flutter analysis must be included on this entry.  

Provides a list of Mach numbers $\mathrm{(m)}$ and reduced frequencies $(\mathbf{k})$ for aerodynamic matrix calculation.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MKAERO2</td><td>m1</td><td>k1</td><td>m2</td><td>k2</td><td>m3</td><td>k3</td><td>m4</td><td>k4</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MKAERO2</td><td>.10</td><td>.30</td><td>.10</td><td>.60</td><td>.70</td><td>.30</td><td>.70</td><td>1.0</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td> mi</td><td>Mach numbers. (Real ≥ 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>ki</td><td>Reduced frequencies. (Real > 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. MKAERO2 willcause the aerodynamic matrices to be computed for the given sets of parameter pairs. Embedded blank pairs are skipped.   
2. No continuation entries are allowed, but multiple MKAERO2 entries are permitted.   
3. In SOL 146,the program selects only one value of mi to use in computing the dynamic response solution and, by default, the lowest value is selected. The PARAM,MACH,m entry may be specified to select a different value. If PARAM,MACH,m is specified, then the value of mi closest to m will be selected.   
4.The very low nonzero value of ki required foraeroelastic divergence analysis ofrestrainedvehicles witl the $\mathrm{K}_{-}$ and KE-methods of flutter analysis must be included on this entry.  

Selects layered composite shelloutput to be placed in Marc's tl6 and/or t19 files and (if requested) to be transferred from Marc to the Nastran Database.The MARCOUT entry with LAYCODE of 3 or 103 must be used in conjunction with this entry. Used in SOL 600 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8 9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MLAYOUT</td><td>L1</td><td>THRU</td><td>L2</td><td>BY L3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>L4</td><td>THRU</td><td>L5</td><td>BY L6</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MLAYOUT</td><td>2</td><td>THRU</td><td>5</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>11</td><td>THRU</td><td>51</td><td>BY</td><td>10</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>52</td><td>THRU</td><td>54</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>21</td><td>THRU</td><td>20</td><td>BY</td><td>10</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td> Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>L1,L4</td><td>Starting layer of a sequence. (Integer; Required; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>L2,L5</td><td>Ending layer of a sequence. (Integer; Default = Llor L4)</td></tr><tr><td>L3,L6</td><td>Increment value for the sequence. (Integer; Default = 1)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. This entry must be used in conjunction with MARCOUT with LAYCODE $_{,=3}$ or 103.   
2. L2 must be larger than L1.   
3. L1, L4, etc. must be positive integers of 1 or larger.   
4. L2,L5 should not exceed the largest number of layers in the model.   
5. Selection of all layers can lead to extremely large output files.   
6.In the example, Ll could also be 1 instead of 2 and thelargest layer could be 55 instead of 54 with causing an error.   
7. If the layers designated on this entry are to apply to selected elements, enter the elements on the T16SEL entry. It is not currently possible to process different layered output for multiple groups of elements (i.e.,it is not currently possible to request output of layers l-20 for some elements and 1-10 for others.)  

Generated by the Marc portion of a SOL 600 execution. Used in SOL 600 only. (See also the MDMIOUT Bulk Data entry.)  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5 6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MNF600</td><td>ID</td><td>ISTRESS</td><td>ISTRAIN</td><td>ISHELL MASSU</td><td>LENGU</td><td>TIMEU</td><td>FORCU</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MNF600</td><td>100</td><td>１</td><td>１</td><td>3</td><td>2</td><td>7</td><td>3</td><td>2</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Subcase for which the reduced matrices will be output. ID must correlate to a SUBCASE Case Control ID, for example, if the case control contains SUBCASE 20, ID would be 20. Must match the MDMIOUT entry. At present, ID is ignored and the first entry will apply to all subcases. (Integer; Default = 1)</td></tr><tr><td>ISTESS (2)</td><td>Flag to compute stress and place in the MNF file (O=no stress, l=stress) (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>ISTRAIN (3)</td><td>Flag to compute strain and place in the MNF file (O=no strain, l=strain) (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>ISHELL (4)</td><td>For shell elements, this entry describes which location the stresses or strains will be output to the MNF file. l=top, 2=center, 3=bottom (Integer; Default = 1)</td></tr><tr><td>MASSU [2,1]</td><td>Mass units for MNF file. (Integer; Default = 1: kilogram) The following possible values may be entered: 1:kilogram (Default) 2:pound mass 3:slug 4:gram</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>LENGU</td><td>Length units for MNF file (Integer; Default = 2: meter) The following possible values may be entered: 1:kilometer 2:meter (Default) 3:centimeter 4:millimeter 5:mile 6:foot</td></tr><tr><td>TIMEU [2,3]</td><td>Time units for MNF file (Integer; Default = 3: second). The following possible values may be entered: 1:hour 2:minute 3:second (Default) 4:millisecond</td></tr><tr><td>FORCEU [2,4]</td><td>Force units for MNF file (Integer; Default = 1: newton). The following possible values may be entered: 1:Newton (Default) 2:poind force 3:kilogram force 4:ounce force 5:dyne 6:kNewton</td></tr></table></body></html>  

# Remarks:  

1. The MDMIOUT entry is the primary entry which generates an MNF file. This entry, MNF600 is only necessary if one or more of the fields is required to define non-default values,for example to generate stresses or strains or to specify the units.   
2. The ID must be the same as the MDMIOUT ID.   
3.Only one MNFDAT entry is allowed in an input file.If more than one is entered, the first will be used.   
4. Alremarks concerning MNF files for the MDMIOUT entry are also applicable to this entry.   
5. (i) Indicates the corresponding field of Marc's MNF Parameter.   
6. [1,j] Indicates the corresponding datablock and field of Marc's MNF units entry.  

Specifies parameters for mode tracking in design optimization (SOL 200).  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MODTRAK</td><td>SID</td><td>LOWRNG</td><td>HIGHRNG</td><td>MTFILTER</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MODTRAK</td><td>100</td><td>1</td><td>26</td><td>0.80</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Sets identification number that is selected in the Case Control Section with the MODTRAK command. See Remark 1. (Integer; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>LOWRNG</td><td>Lowest mode number in range to search. See Remark 2. (Integer ≥ O; Default = 0. If nonzero,LOWRNG<HIGHRNG.)</td></tr><tr><td>HIGHRNG</td><td>Highest mode number in range to search. See Remark 2. (Integer > 0; Default =number of eigenvalues extracted. If nonzero, LOWRNG < HIGHRNG.)</td></tr><tr><td>MTFILTER</td><td>Filtering parameter used in mode cross-orthogonality check. See Remark 3. (Real; Default = 0.9)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Only the designed modes for the subcase willbe tracked. A designed mode is one that is used in the design model (in connection with either objective or constraints) and, therefore, identified on a DRESP1 entry.   
2. The range of modes LOWRNG through HIGHRNG, inclusive, willbe used to track the designed modes. If LOWRNG and HIGHRNG are both blank, then all computed modes will be used to search for the designed modes. Since large numbers of computed modes will result in higher computational costs, limiting the search range with LOWRNG and HIGHRNG is recommended.   
3. Modes are considered to correlate if their mass normalized crossorthogonalities are greater than MTFILTER.  

Defines a static concentrated moment load on a ring of a conical shell.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>MOMAX</td><td>SID</td><td>RID</td><td>HID</td><td>S</td><td>MR</td><td>MP</td><td>MZ</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MOMAX</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>1.0</td><td>0.1</td><td>0.2</td><td>0.3</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>RID</td><td>Ring identification number. See the RINGAX entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>HID</td><td>Harmonic identification number or a sequence of harmonics. See Remark 5. (Integer ≥ O or Character)</td></tr><tr><td>S</td><td>Scale factor. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>MR,MP, MZ</td><td> Moment components in the r, Φ,z directions. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. MOMAX is allowed only if an AXIC entry is also present.   
2. Load sets must be selected with the Case Control command LOAD $\mid=$ SID.   
3. A separate entry is needed for the definition of the moment associated with each harmonic.   
4.For a discusson of the conical shell problem, seeConical ShellElement (RINGAX) (p.145) in the MSC Nastran Reference Guide.   
5.Ifasequence of harmonics is to be placed in HID, the form is as follows:“Sn1Tn2",where nl is the start of the sequence and $\mathrm{n}2$ is the end of the sequence; i.e., for harmonics O through 10, the field would contain“SoT10".  

Defines astatic concentrated moment at agrid point by specifying a scale factor anda vector that determines the direction.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MOMENT</td><td>SID</td><td>G</td><td>CID</td><td>M</td><td>N1</td><td>N2</td><td>N3</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MOMENT</td><td>2</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>2.9</td><td>0.0</td><td>1.0</td><td>0.0</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td> Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>G</td><td>Grid point identification number at which the moment is applied. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>CID</td><td>Coordinate system identification number. (Integer ≥ O or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>M</td><td>Scale factor. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>Ni</td><td>Components of the vector measured in the coordinate system defined by CID. (Real; at least one Ni ≠ O.0 unless M is zero)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The static moment applied to grid point $G$ is given by  

$$
\vec{\bf m}={\bf M}\vec{\bf N}
$$  

where $\vec{\bf N}$ is the vector defined by (N1, N2, N3).The magnitude of $\vec{\mathrm{m}}$ is equal to M times the magnitude of $\vec{\bf N}$ ·  

2. In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command.  

In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry.  

3. A CID of zero or blank references the basic coordinate system.  

4. For scalar points see SLOAD.  

5.For $\mathrm{TYPE}{=}12$ or $\mathrm{TYPE}{=}13$ on the TLOAD1, G is the ID ofa rigid body: the MID of a rigid material (MATRIG) or the EID of a RBE2D. The MID of a rigid material and the EID of RBE2 must be different when both of a RBE2D and a rigid material are used with these TYPEs. SOL 700 only.  

Defines a concentrated moment at a grid point by specifying a magnitude and two grid points that determine the direction.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MOMENT1</td><td>SID</td><td>G</td><td>M</td><td>G1</td><td>G2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MOMENT1</td><td>6</td><td>13</td><td>-2.93</td><td>16</td><td>13</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>G</td><td>Grid point identification number at which the moment is applied. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>M</td><td>Magnitude of moment. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>G1,G2</td><td>Grid point identification numbers used to define the unit vector n. (Integer > 0; G1 and G2 cannot be coincident.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The concentrated moment applied to grid point G is given by $\vec{\bf m}={\bf M}\vec{\bf n}$ where $\vec{\bf n}$ is a unit vector parallel to a vector from G1 to G2.  

2. In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command.  

In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry. 3.The follower force effects due toloads from this entry are included in the stiffnessinallinear solution sequences that calculate a differential stiffness.The solution sequences are SOLs 103, 105, 107 to 112,115 and 116 (see also the parameter FOLLowK, 829). In addition, follower force effects are included in the force balance in the nonlinear static and nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences, SOLs 106, 129, 153,159, and 400, if geometric nonlinear effects are turned on with PARAM,LGDISP,1.The follower force stiffnes is included in the nonlinear static solution sequences (SOLs 106, 153 and 400) but not in the nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences (SOLs 129 and 159).  

Defines a concentrated moment at a grid point by specification of a magnitude and four grid points that determine the direction.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MOMENT2</td><td>SID</td><td>G</td><td>M</td><td>G1</td><td>G2</td><td>G3</td><td>G4</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MOMENT2</td><td>6</td><td>13</td><td>-2.93</td><td>16</td><td>13</td><td>17</td><td>13</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>G</td><td>Grid point identification number at which the moment is applied. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>M</td><td>Magnitude of moment. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>Gi</td><td>Grid point identification numbers used to determine the unit vector n. (Integer > 0; G1 and G2 cannot be coincident; G3 and G4 cannot be coincident.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The concentrated moment applied to grid point G is given by  

$\vec{\bf m}={\bf M}\vec{\bf n}$ where $\vec{\bf n}$ is the unit vector parallel to the cross product of the vectors from G1 to G2, and G3 to G4.   
2. In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command. In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry.   
3.The follower force effects due to loads from this entry are included in the stiffnessin allinear solution sequences that calculate a differential stiffness. The solution sequences are SOLs 103, 105,107 to 112, 115 and 116 (see also the parameter FOLLowK, 829). In addition,follower force effects are included in the force balance in the nonlinear static and nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences, SOLs 106, 129, 153,159, and 400if geometric nonlinear effects are turned on with PARAM,LGDISP,1.The follower force stiffnes is included in the nonlinear static solution sequences (SOLs 106, 153 and 400) but not in the nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences (SOLs 129 and 159).  

Parameters for conducting Monte-Carlo simulation using the non-parametric variability method (NPVM)  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>５</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>９</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MONCARL</td><td>SID</td><td>VARTYP</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>STRVAR</td><td>MSVAR</td><td>KSVAR</td><td>BSVAR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>FLUVAR</td><td>MFVAR</td><td>KFVAR</td><td>BFVAR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MONCARL</td><td>100</td><td>DELTAVAR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>STRVAR</td><td>0.001</td><td>0.05</td><td>0.002</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>FLUVAR</td><td>0.0</td><td>0.001</td><td>0.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number referenced by MONCARL case control. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="3">VARTYP</td><td>Select the type of variabilities that follow (Character; Default = ALPHAVAR)</td></tr><tr><td>ALPHAVAR Variabilities in this entry are Alpha variabilities.</td></tr><tr><td>DELTAVAR Variabilities in this entry are Delta variabilities.</td></tr><tr><td>“STRVAR"</td><td>Indicates Structural variability parameters follow. (String)</td></tr><tr><td>MSVAR</td><td>Structural mass variability. (Real >= 0.0; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>KSVAR</td><td>Structural stiffness variability. (Real >= O.0; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>BSVAR</td><td> Structural damping variability. (Real >= 0.0; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>“FLUVAR”</td><td> Indicates Fluid variability parameters follow (String)</td></tr><tr><td>MFVAR</td><td>Fluid mass variability. (Real >= 0.0; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>KFVAR</td><td>Fluid stiffness variability. (Real >= O.O; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>BFVAR</td><td>Fluid damping variability. (Real >= 0.0; Default = 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

# Remarks  

1.Please use below as the guidelinefor selecting above mentioned structuraland fluid alpha variabilities (which should be $>0.0$ ）  

a. Low variability level $\mathbf{\tau}=0.001$ b. Medium variability level $=0.01$  

c. High variability level $=0.05$  

2.Alpha variabilities are related to delta variabilities through the order of the matrix to be randomized. $n$ (or equivalently the number of modes),  

$$
{\mathrm{~a~}=\sqrt[8]{\frac{2}{{\mathrm{n}}+1}}}
$$  

3.Thre is a limitation in the admissible values for the variability level. The maximum value for delta variability equals,  

$$
8_{\mathrm{max}}~=~{\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{n+1}}{\mathrm{n+5}}}}
$$  

On a model with a large amount of modes $\scriptstyle(n>>1)$ ), the maximum value of delta tends to 1 $(?_{m a x}{\approx}1)$ · The maximum value of alpha variability using the above equations equals,  

$$
{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{max}}={\sqrt{\frac{2}{{\mathrm{n}}+{\bar{5}}}}}
$$  

4.An unphysical (larger than permisible or negative value) selection ofa variability would results in a FATAL.  

Provides a stripwise aerodynamic normal force and pitching moment coeficients for CAERO1 based aerodynamics.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>９</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MONCNCM</td><td>NAME</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>LABEL</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>MREF</td><td>CAERID1</td><td>CAERID2</td><td>…</td><td>CAERIDn</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MONCNCM</td><td>LEFT</td><td colspan="6">Normal force and pitching moment values for strips on the left wing.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>2001</td><td>3001</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>NAME</td><td>Unique character string of up to 8 characters identifying the family of chord-wise strips. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>LABEL</td><td>A string comprising no more than 56 characters (fields 3 through 9) that identifies and labels the component. (Optional)</td></tr><tr><td>MREF</td><td>Fractional chord location of the aerodynamic strip about which the pitching moment is to be calculated. (Real;≤0.0MREF ≤1.0; Default = 0.25)</td></tr><tr><td>CAERID1</td><td>ID of a CAER0l entry that contains aero boxes for which strip results are to be produced. (Integer > O or“ALL"). See Remarks 2. and 3.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The LABEL is optional.   
2. Output is produced for all chordwise strips on the referenced CAERO1 entries.If a strip spans CAEROl panels, results are output for the total strip.   
3.If CAERID1 is the character string “ALL", then output will be produced for all strips.   
4. Strips are identified based on the y and z coordinates in the aerodynamic coordinate system.   
5. If strips from separate CAEROl's have the same y and z coordinate and the same strip width and share an xlocation (i.e., the leading edge ofone strip equals the trailing edge from another) then they are processed as a single strip.   
6. The normal force component is normalized by the dynamic pressure times the surface area of the strip. The moment component is normalized by the dynamic pressure times the surface area of the strip times the chord length at the center of the strip.The moment is calculated about the MREF location of the strip with the quarter-chord of the strip as the default.  

7. Only CAERO1 id's are supported.  

Defines a virtual point displacement response at a user-defined reference location (coordinates and coordinates system) as a weighted average of the motions at a set of grid points.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MONDSP1</td><td>NAME</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>LABEL</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>AXES</td><td>COMP</td><td>CP</td><td>X</td><td>Y</td><td>Z</td><td>CD</td><td>INDDOF</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MONDSP1 WING195</td><td colspan="5">Wing twist at station 150.</td></tr><tr><td>5</td><td>WING150 1001</td><td>120</td><td>150.0</td><td>17.0 1002</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>NAME</td><td>Character string of up to 8 characters identifying the monitor point (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>LABEL</td><td>A string comprising no more than 56 characters (fields 3 through 9) that identifies and labels the monitor point.</td></tr><tr><td>AXES</td><td>Component axes to monitor. (Any unique combination of the integers 1 through 6 with no embedded blanks.)</td></tr><tr><td>COMP</td><td>The name of an AECOMP or AECOMPL entry that defines the set of grid points over which the monitor point is defined.</td></tr><tr><td>CP</td><td>The identification number of a coordinate system in which the input (x,y,z) coordinates are defined. (Integer ≥ 0; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>X,YZ</td><td>The coordinates in the CP coordinate system at which the displacement is to be monitored.</td></tr><tr><td>CD</td><td>The identification number of a coordinate system in which the resulting displacement components are output. (Integer ≥ O; Default = the coordinate system specified by the CP field)</td></tr><tr><td>INDDOF</td><td>Component numbers of allthe independent grids from which the derived, dependent, monitor DOF's are to be computed. (Any unique combination of the integers 1 through 6 with no embedded blanks.) See Remark 3. (Default = 123)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1． The MONDSP1 is available for SOLs 101,103,105,108,109,111,112, 144,146 and 200.   
2. The entry can create either an aerodynamic or a structural MONDSP1, depending on the data provided in the COMP field.A structural MONDSPl can have the same name as an aerodynamic MONDSPl, but two structural or two aerodynamic MONDSPls cannot have the same name.  

3.The INDDOF field defines the Ci field on the virtual RBE3; that is,it defines the components of the grids on the AECOMP that will be sampled to define the dependent (monitor point) displacement. Typically, the default is the correct choice. However, if there is only a single grid point, all six DOF's can be used.  

Defines a collection of monitor points into a group available for postprocessing  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>５</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>９</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MONGRP</td><td>GNAME</td><td>LABEL</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>NAME1</td><td>CLASS1</td><td>REAL1</td><td>INT1</td><td>STRING1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>NAME2</td><td>CLASS2</td><td>REAL2</td><td>INT2</td><td>STRING2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>NAME(m)</td><td>CLASS(m)</td><td>REAL(m)</td><td>INT(m)</td><td>STRING(m)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MONGRP</td><td>WING</td><td colspan="7">A COLLECTION OFMONITORPOINTS ON THE WING</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>WING195</td><td>SMONPT1</td><td></td><td>1</td><td>WL195</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>WING205</td><td>SMONPT1</td><td></td><td>2</td><td>WL205</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>WINGDSP</td><td>SMONDP1</td><td>20.0</td><td></td><td>GRID20</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>GNAME</td><td>A character string of up to 8 characters identifying the monitor group. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>LABEL</td><td>A String comprising no more than 56 characters (fields 3 through 9) that identifies and labels the monitor point.</td></tr><tr><td>NAME(i)</td><td>Name of an existing monitor point. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>CLASS(i)</td><td>Type of monitor point (either AMONPT1, AMONDP1, SMONPT1, SMONDP1, MONPT2,MONTP3)</td></tr><tr><td>REAL(i)</td><td>Optional real value to designate a real property of the monitor point.</td></tr><tr><td>INT(i)</td><td>Optional integer value to designate a integer property of the monitor point.</td></tr><tr><td>STRING</td><td>A label of the current monitor type. (Character string of no more than 32 character)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The MONGRP entry provides the user a means of specifying groups of monitor point data but does not produce any output on its own.   
2. Aerodynamic (AMONPT1 and AMONDP1) and structural (SMONPT1, SMONDP1, MONPT2, MONPT3) cannot be mixed in a given group.   
3.The REAL(i),INT(i)and STRING(i) data are provided to facilitate user display of the monitor data and can be used, for example, to label xy plots.   
4. The LABEL should be unique across MONGRP entries.  

Defines an integrated load monitor point at a point $(\mathrm{x},\mathrm{y},\mathrm{z})$ in a user defined coordinate system. (Any unique combination of the integers 1 through 6 with no embedded blanks.)</td></tr><tr><td>COMP</td><td>The name of an AECOMP or AECOMPL entry that defines the set of grid points over which the monitor point is defined. Remarks:  

1. The MONPNT1 is available for SOLs 101,108,109, 111,112, 144,146,200 and 400 1 $\mathrm{\DeltaANALYSIS=NLSTAT}$ or NLTRAN).   
2. The entry can create either an aerodynamic or a structural MONPNT1, depending on the data provided in the COMP field.A structural MONPNT1 can have the same name as an aerodynamic MONPNT1, but two structural or two aerodynamic MONPNTls cannot have the same name.  

3. In SOL 144, static aeroelasticity, the structural MONPNT1 integration is modified to account for the redistribution of loads and inertia caused by MPCs and rigid elements. In all other supported solution sequences, the integration is done using the g-set loads on all grid points specified on the referenced SET1 entry.

# Remarks:  

1． The MONPNT3 is available for SOLs 101, 103,108,109,111,112, 144,146,200 and 400 (ANALYSIS $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ NLSTAT or NLTRAN). Note that MONPNT3 output to csv file is available only to SOL144.  

2. If ELEMSET is blank, no contributions are made from the set of elements atached to the grid.  

3. Fictitious grids or elements do not produce error or warning messages.  

4.For linear solution sequences,if the exclusion flags omit some grid point force types but not all of them (i.e; if the field is not blank and is not SMAD) then the following limitations exist:  

The results for that MONPNT3 will not be exported to a CSV file, for SOL 144 only. That MONPNT3 may not be used on a MONSUM, MONSUM1 or MONSUMT entry. · It is only available in SOLs 101, 103, 144 and SOL 200 (ANALYSIS $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ STATICS, MODES, 01 SAERO).  

5. MONPNT3 can be useful in calculating shear, moment and torque from the internal loads in a structure.For example, if a split is made ina fuselage component and allthe grids that reside on this split are placed in the GRIDSET, differing internal loads resultants can be obtained based on the ELEMSET and XFLAG values. If a cut is made in a structure, there are three types of loads:  

A - loads that come from the elements upstream of the cut.   
B - loads that are applied to the grids on the cut from any other source.   
C - loads that come from the elements downstream of the cut.  

Where $\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B}+\mathrm{C}=0$  

Useful options for these two values are:  

a. If the ELEMSET includes all the elements that connect to the GRIDSET that are on the upstream/outboard part of the split and the XFLAG value is blank then the internal load is calculated using the elements that connect to the GRIDSET that are NOT included in ELEMSET. The direction of this load is reversed. So actually -C will be calculated which matches $_\mathrm{A+B}$ . This in effect gives the resultants on the downstream/inboard side of the split pointing into upstream/ outboard direction which will include any loads applied to the GRIDSET from any source.   
b. If the ELEMSET includes all the elements that connect to the GRIDSET that are on the upstream/outboard part of the split and the XFLAG value is SMAD then the internal load is calculated using the elements listed in ELEMSET.In that case, A willbe calculated.This in effct gives the resultants on the upstream/outboard side of the split and does not include loads applied to the GRIDSET from any other source.  

5. For SOL 400 (ANALYSIS $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ NLSTAT or NLTRAN), the following limitations exist:  

The results for that MONPNT3 will not be exported to a CSV file, for SOL 144 only. $\cdot\cdot$ That MONPNT3 may not be used on a MONSUM, MONSUM1 or MONSUMT entry. Thermal loads are not supported.  

7. For linear solution sequences with XFLAG $\mathbf{\sigma}=\mathbf{\sigma}$ blank or SMAD, the program applies a mini-EMA (element matrix assembly) algorithm that bypasses GPFDR (grid point force data recovery) and another modules to improve performance. This algorithm forms a stiffness matrix that just includes those elements specified in MONPNT3 entries. The monitor point results are computed directly from multiplying this matrix by an integration matrix that transfers forces to the monitor points. These results may be slightly different from the GPFDR results, such as clean zero forces versus small residual forces.  

Defines a new monitor result that is the weighted sum of existing monitor results.The existing monitor points do not need to be of the same type but they must be of similar type (see Remark 5.)

(any unique combination of the integers 1 to 6 with no embedded blanks)</td></tr><tr><td>COEFij</td><td>Coefficient to be applied to the component(s) called out on AXESij field. (Real; Default = 1.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The MONSUM is available in SOLs 101,103,108,109,111,112,144,146,200 and 400 (ANALYSI $S=]$ NLSTAT or NLTRAN).  

2. The LABEL is a 56 character string that should be unique.  

3. The MONSUM can be used to update an existing monitor result by setting all the NAMEij terms equal to NAME. In this case, the alternate format is available and the NEWAXISj component is a scalar multiple of the original component:  

$$
M O N S U M j=M R j C O E F j
$$  

4. When the NAME differs from the NAMEij values, it must be unique with respect to all monitor quantities.The result of the MONSUM entry is to create new monitor point(s) that are equal to:  

$$
\mathrm{MONSUM_{j}\ =\sum_{i}C O E F_{\mathrm{ij}}M R_{\mathrm{ij}}}
$$  

where $\mathrm{MR}_{\mathrm{ij}}$ is the result from the individual component.  

5. The merged monitor points must be of a similar type.“Similar" types are defined as: Force and moment summation monitor points: AMONPNT1, SMONPNT1, MONPNT3 Average displacement monitor points: AMONDSP1 and SMONDSP1  

6. For MONPNT1's and MONDSPl's, the MTYPij can be aerodynamic or structural. MTYPij $\begin{array}{r}{=}{{}}\\ {{}}\end{array}$ AMxxxl designates aerodynamic while SMxxxl designates a structural monitor point.  

7. If multiple components are to be summed, the NEWAXISj field must be the union of subsequent AXISij fields. If the subsequent AXISij field is blank, the components are determined from NEWAXISj.  

8.If the NEWAXISj field indicates a single output, the AXISij fields must reference a single input, but it can be any value from 1 to 6.  

9. The same component cannot be referenced multiple times on the NEWAXISj fields for a single MONSUM entry.  

10. Structural monitor points may span superelements.  

11.If multiple types are specified on a MONSUM,the resulting entry is of a type that appears on the MONSUM with the following order of precedence: smonpntl, smondspl, monpnt3, amonpntl, amondspl. E.g., a amonpntl and a monpnt3 appearing on the same entry willresult in a monpnt3 regardless of which appears first.   
12.If allthe MTYPij values are of the same type, the alternate format provides a simplified interface.   
13. A MONSUM can reference another MONSUM (including itself) as long as there is not a circular reference. A MONSUM cannot reference another MONSUM1.   
14.MONPNT3's that have one, two or three excluded items (e.g.,XFLAG $\dot{\mathbf{\eta}}=\mathbf{\eta}$ SMA) cannot be referenced on a MONSUM.   
15. Since CP,X,Y,Z and CD are not known with certainty fora MONSUM, they are not printed as part of the monitor point output. Further, in SOL's 101 and 1 $44,\mathrm{COMP=^{**}S U M^{**}}$ is used to indicate that the associated monitor point has been derived from a MONSUM.
