See Remarks 3. and 4.</td></tr><tr><td>NAMEij</td><td>Name of the monitored quantity that is to be summed.</td></tr><tr><td>AXESij</td><td>Component axes that are to be scaled. (any unique combination of the integers 1 to 6 with no embedded blanks. Must be a subset of NEWAXESj).Default =same as NEWAXESj</td></tr><tr><td>COEFij</td><td>Scaling coefficient to be applied to the component(s) called out on AXESij field. (Real, Default=1.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The LABEL is a 56 character string that should be unique  

2. The result of the MONSUMl entry is to create new monitor point(s) as follows:  

$$
\mathrm{MONSUM1_{j}\ =\sum_{i}^{n}C O E F_{j i}M R_{i}}
$$  

Where $\mathbf{M}\mathbf{R}_{\mathrm{i}}$ is the result from the individual component.  

3. The merged monitor points must be of a similar type.“Similar” types are defined as:  

Force and moment summation monitor points: AMONPNT1, SMONPNT1, MONPNT3  

4. For MONPNT1's the MTYPij can be aerodynamic or structural. MTYPij $\O=$ AMONPT1 designates aerodynamic while SMONPNT1 designates a structural monitor point.  

5. If multiple components are to be summed, the NEWAXISjfield must be the union of subsequent AXISij fields. If the subsequent AXISij field is blank, the components are the same as NEWAXISj.  

6.If the NEWAXISj field indicates a single output, the AXISij fields must reference a single input, but it can be any value from 1 to 6. There may be as many as 6 AXISij and COEFij for each referenced NAMEij.   
7. The same component cannot be referenced multiple times on the NEWAXISj fields for a single MONSUM1 entry.   
8.If multiple types are specified on a MONSUMl, the resulting entry is of a type that appears on the MONSUM1 with the following order of precedence: SMONPNT1 (structural MONPNT1), MONPNT3, AMONPNT1 (aerodynamic MONPNT1). E.g., a AMONPNT1 (aerodynamic MONPNT1) and a MONPNT3 appearing on the same entry willresult in a MONPNT3 regardles of which appears first.   
9. A MONSUMl can reference the results of another MONSUMlor a MONSUMT as long as there is not a circular reference.   
10. The MONSUM1 entry is available in SOLs 101,103,108,109,111,112,144,146,200 and 400 (ANALYSIS $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ NLSTAT or NLTRAN).   
11.The CP, CD, and XY Z location coordinates are for reference only and do not affect the calculations.  

Defines a new monitor result that is the sum of existing monitor results.The existing monitor points do not need to be of the same type but they must be of similar type (See Remark 3) 3.)  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MONSUMT</td><td>NAME</td><td>LABEL</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>AXES</td><td>CP</td><td>X</td><td>Y</td><td>Z</td><td>CD</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>MTYP1</td><td>NAME1a</td><td>NAME1b</td><td>NAME1c</td><td>NAME1d</td><td>NAME1e</td><td>NAME1f</td><td>NAME1g</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>MTYP2</td><td>NAME2a</td><td>NAME2b</td><td>NAME2c</td><td>NAME2d</td><td>NAME2e</td><td>NAME2f</td><td>NAME2g</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example: Create a new monitor point result by adding an aerodynamic and a monpnt3  

<html><body><table><tr><td>MONSUMT</td><td>FS_900</td><td colspan="7">FUSELAGE STATION 900</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>123456</td><td></td><td>500.</td><td>0.0</td><td>25.0</td><td>20</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>MONPNT3</td><td>FS_1000</td><td>FS_1100</td><td>FS_1200</td><td>MONPNT3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>AMONPNT1</td><td>HTP_ROOT</td><td>AMONPNT1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>NAME</td><td>Character string of up to 8 characters identifying the monitor result (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>LABEL</td><td>A string comprising no more than 56 characters (fields 3 through 9) that identifies and labels the merged monitor result.</td></tr><tr><td>CP</td><td>The identification number of a coordinate system in which the input (x,y,z) coordinates are defined. (Integer > 0; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>X,Y,Z</td><td>The coordinates in the CP coordinate system about which the loads are to be monitored. (Real; Default = 0.0).</td></tr><tr><td>CD</td><td>The identification number of a coordinate system in which the resulting load components are output. (Integer > O; Default = the coordinate system specified by the CP field)</td></tr><tr><td>AXES</td><td>The component axis of the newly-created monitor point into which the summed quantity will be stored (integer, any unique combination of the integers 1 to 6 with no embedded blanks.</td></tr><tr><td>MTYPi</td><td>Monitor type to be merged.(Character, one of“AMONPNT1", “SMONPNT1”,or “MONPNT3", no default). See Remarks 3. and 4.</td></tr><tr><td>NAMEij</td><td>Name of the monitored quantity that is to be summed.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The LABEL is a 56 character string that should be unique.   
2. The NAME must be unique with respect to all monitor quantities. The result of the MONSUMT entry is to create new monitor point(s) as follows:  

n  

$$
\mathrm{MONSUMT_{j}=\sum_{i}T_{j i}M R_{i}}
$$  

Where $\mathbf{M}\mathbf{R}_{\mathrm{i}}$ is the result from the monitor points being summed and $\mathrm{T_{ji}}$ is set of partial rigid body vectors for thelocations of the monitor points being summed, with the origin at the X, Y, Z location.  

). The summed monitor points must be of a similar type.“Similar" types are defined as:  

$\mathbf{\delta}_{\mathbf{\overline{{\Pi}}}}\mathbf{\Pi}_{\mathbf{\overline{{\Pi}}}}\mathbf{\Pi}_{\overline{{\mathbf{\Pi}}}}\mathbf{\Pi}_{\overline{{\mathbf{\Pi}}}}\mathbf{\Pi}_{\overline{{\mathbf{\Pi}}}}\mathbf{\Pi}_{\overline{{\mathbf{\Pi}}}}\mathbf{\Pi}_{\overline{{\mathbf{\Pi}}}}\mathbf{\Pi}_{\overline{{\mathbf{\Pi}}}}\mathbf{\Pi}_{\overline{{\mathbf{\Pi}}}}\mathbf{\Pi}_{\overline{{\mathbf{\Pi}}}}\mathbf{\Pi}_{\overline{{\mathbf{\Pi}}}}$ Force and moment summation monitor points: AMONPNT1, SMONPNT1, MONPNT3  

4. For MONPNT1's the MTYPij can be aerodynamic or structural. MTYPij $\begin{array}{r}{=}{{}}\\ {\overline{{\mathbf{\sigma}}}}\end{array}$ AMONPT1 designates aerodynamic while SMONPNT1 designates a structural monitor point.  

5.If multiple types are specified on a MONSUMT, the resulting entry is of a type that appears on the MONSUMT with the following order of precedence: If multiple types are specified on a MONSUM1,the resulting entry is ofa typethat appears on the MONSUM1 with thefollowing order of precedence: SMONPNT1 (structural MONPNT1), MONPNT3, AMONPNT1 (aerodynamic MONPNT1). E.g.,a AMONPNT1 (aerodynamic MONPNT1) and a MONPNT3 appearing on the same entry will result in a MONPNT3 regardless of which appears first.  

6. A MONSUMT can reference the results of another MONSUMT or a MONSUM1 as long as there is not a circular reference.  

7. The MONSUMT entry is available in SOLs 101,103,108,109,111,112,144,146, 200 and 400 (ANALYSIS $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ NLSTAT or NLTRAN).  

Defines a multipoint constraint equation of the form $\sum_{\mathrm{j}}\mathrm{A_{j}\ \mathrm{u_{j}}}=\mathrm{0}$ where $u_{j}$ represents degree-of-freedom Cj at grid or scalar point Gj  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MPC</td><td>SID</td><td>G1</td><td>C1</td><td>A1</td><td>G2</td><td>C2</td><td>A2</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>G3</td><td>C3</td><td>A3</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MPC</td><td>3</td><td>28</td><td>3</td><td>6.2</td><td>2</td><td></td><td>4.29</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>1</td><td>4</td><td>-2.91</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Gj</td><td>Identification number of grid or scalar point. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Cj</td><td>Component number. (Any one of the Integers 1 through 6 for grid points; blank, zero or 1 for scalar points.)</td></tr><tr><td>Aj</td><td>Coefficient. (Real; Default = 0.0 except A1 must be nonzero.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Multipoint constraint sets must be selected with the Case Control command ${\mathrm{MPC}}={\mathrm{SID}}$   
2. The first degree-of-freedom (G1, C1) in the sequence is defined to be the dependent degree-offreedom. A dependent degree-of-freedom assigned by one MPC entry cannot be assigned dependent by another MPC entry or by a rigid element.   
3.Forces of multipoint constraint may be recovered in allsolution sequences, except SOL 129, with the MPCFORCE Case Control command.   
4.The m-set degrees-of-freedom specified on this entry may not be specified on other entries that define mutually exclusive sets. See the“Degree-of-Freedom Sets"on page 1557 for a list of these entries.   
5. By default, the grid point connectivity created by the MPC, MPCADD, and MPCAX entries is not considered during resequencing, (see the PARAM,OLDSEQ description in “Parameters” on page 1409). In order to consider the connectivity during resequencing, SID must be specified on the PARAM,MPCX entry. Using the example above, specify PARAM,MPCX,3.  

Defines a multipoint constraint set as a union of multipoint constraint sets defined via MPC entries.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4 5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MPCADD</td><td>SID</td><td>S1</td><td>S2</td><td>S3 S4</td><td>S5</td><td>S6</td><td>S7</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>S8</td><td>S9</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MPCADD</td><td>101</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>1</td><td>6</td><td>4</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td> Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Sj </td><td>Set identification numbers of multipoint constraint sets defined via MPC entries. (Integer > 0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Multipoint constraint sets must be selected with the Case Control command ${\mathrm{MPC}}={\mathrm{SID}}$ ·   
2. The Sj must be unique and may not be the identification number of a multipoint constraint set defined by another MPCADD entry.   
3. MPCADD entries take precedence over MPC entries. If both have the same SID, only the MPCADD entry will be used.   
4. By default, the grid point connectivity created by the MPC, MPCADD, and MPCAX entries is not considered during resequencing, (see the PARAM,OLDSEQ description in “Parameters" on page l409). In order to consider the connectivity during resequencing, SID must be specified on the PARAM,MPCX entry. Using the example above, specify PARAM,MPCX,101.  

5. If Modules are present then this entry may only be specified in the main Bulk Data section.  

Defines a multipoint constraint equation of the form  

$$
\sum_{\mathrm{j}}\mathrm{A}_{\mathrm{j}}\mathrm{\u}_{\mathrm{j}}=0
$$  

for conical shell coordinates, where $u_{j}$ represents the degree-of-freedom Cj at ring RIDj and harmonic HIDj.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MPCAX</td><td>SID</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>RID1</td><td>HID1</td><td>C1</td><td>A1</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>RID2</td><td>HID2</td><td>C2</td><td>A2</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MPCAX 32</td><td></td><td></td><td>17</td><td>6 1</td><td>1.0</td></tr><tr><td>23</td><td>4</td><td>2</td><td>-6.8</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>RIDj </td><td>Ring identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>HIDj</td><td>Harmonic identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Cj </td><td>Component number. (1 ≤ Integer ≤ 6)</td></tr><tr><td>Aj</td><td>Coefficient. (Real; Default = 0.0 except A1 must be nonzero.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. MPCAX is allowed only if an AXIC entry is also present.   
2. The first degree-of-freedom in the sequence is assumed to be the dependent degree-of-freedom. A dependent degree-of-freedom assigned by one MPCAX entry cannot be assgned dependent by another MPCAX entry.   
3. Multipoint constraint sets must be selected with the Case Control command ${\mathrm{MPC}}={\mathrm{SID}}$   
4. Dependent degrees-of-freedom appearing on MPCAX entries may not appear on OMITAX, SPCAX, or SUPAX entries.   
5.See Conical Shel Element (RINGAX) (Ch.3) in the MSC Nastran Reference Guide for further discussion of the problem.   
6. By default, the grid point connectivity created by the MPC, MPCADD, and MPCAX entries is not considered during resequencing, (see the PARAM,OLDSEQ description in “Parameters" on page 1409). In order to consider the connectivity during resequencing, SID must be specified on the PARAM,MPCX entry. Using the example above, specify PARAM,MPCX,32.  

Defines a load selectable value for $\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{m}}$ of a MPCY entry.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MPCD</td><td>SID</td><td>GM1</td><td>CM1</td><td>YM1</td><td>GM2</td><td>CM2</td><td>YM2</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MPCD</td><td>700</td><td>101</td><td>2</td><td>.06</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number of the MPCD entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>GMi</td><td>Grid or scalar point identification number. Along with Ci it identifies the Equation of a MPCY. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Ci</td><td>Component number. (Any one of the Integers 1 through 6 for grid points, blank, zero or 1 for scalar points.)</td></tr><tr><td>YMi</td><td>Right hand side value of MPC equation. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. In static solution sequences, the SID is selected by the LOAD Case Control command.   
2. The Gi,Ci referenced on this entry must also be referenced on a MPCY Bulk Data entry and selected   
by an MPC Case Control command.   
3. Values YMi willoverride the value specified on an MPCY Bulk Data entry.   
4. The LOAD Bulk Data entry will not combine an MPCD load entry.   
5. Two separate MPC equations may be pointed to per entry.  

Specifies input values for Marc's creep parameter when creep analysis is performed using SOL 600 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>MPCEEP</td><td>ITYPE</td><td>IMPLK</td><td>IMPLM</td><td>IHOW</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MPCREEP</td><td>1</td><td>0</td><td>0</td><td>0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="2">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ITYPE</td><td colspan="2">Type of explicit creep analysis enter one of the following: (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">IMPLK</td><td>0</td><td> Normal creep (Maxwell Model)</td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td>Viscoplastic creep</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>Viscoplastic creep with nonassociative flow rule.</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">Flag determining if the explicit Kelvin model is to be used. (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="3">IMPLM</td><td>0 Explicit Kelvin model is not used</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td>Explicit Kelvin model is used.</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">Flag determiningif the implicit Maxwell creep or implicit viscoplastic model is to be used. (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">IHOW</td><td>0 These models are not used.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td> The implicit Maxwell creep or implicit viscoplastic model is used.</td></tr><tr><td>(Integer; Default = 0)</td><td> Flag specifying how the Maxwell creep model or implicit viscoplastic model is used.</td></tr><tr><td>0 Use elastic tangent</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Use secant tangent</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>1</td><td>Use radial return</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Set $\scriptstyle{\mathrm{IHOW}=0}$ or leave field blank if IMPLM $_{.=0}$   
2. When using the implicit Maxwell creep model, the stress dependence must be in exponential form and the CRPLAW user subroutine cannot be used.   
3. Only one MPCREEP entry may be entered in the input.Ifadditional MPCREEP entries are found, the first will be used.   
4.If $\mathrm{ITYPE}>0$ , Bulk Data entry, MACREEP or MTCREEP is required in addition to this entry.  

5. This entry maps to Marc's CREEP parameter.   
6. This entry is not necessary if fields 2-5 are all zero or blank   
7. Kelvin creep requires user subroutines.  

Defines a multipoint constraint equation of the form  

$$
\mathrm{A_{m}\mathrm{u_{m}}+\sum_{i}\mathrm{A_{i}\mathrm{u_{i}}=\mathrm{Y_{m}}}}
$$  

where $\mathtt{u}_{\mathrm{m}}$ represents degree-of-freedom $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{m}}$ at grid or scalar point $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{m}}$ defined to be the dependent degreeof-freedom. $\mathbf{u}_{\mathrm{i}}$ represents degree-of-freedom $\mathrm{{C}_{i}}$ at grid or scalar point $\mathrm{G_{i}}$ defined to be the independent degree-of-freedom. $\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{m}}$ is a value for the equation.

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>MPCY</td><td>SID</td><td>GM</td><td>CM</td><td>AM</td><td>YM</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>G1</td><td>C1</td><td>A1</td><td>G2</td><td>C2</td><td>A2</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>G3</td><td>C3</td><td>A3</td><td>…</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MPCY</td><td>70</td><td>205</td><td>1</td><td>1.0</td><td>.02-3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>1608</td><td>１</td><td>1.2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number of a multi-point constraint set. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>GM</td><td>Identification number of grid or scalar point. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Cj </td><td>Component number. (Any one of the Integers 1 through 6 for grid points; blank, zero or 1 for scalar points.)</td></tr><tr><td>AM</td><td>Coefficient. (Real nonzero value)</td></tr><tr><td>YM</td><td>Right hand side value. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>Gi</td><td>Identification number of grid or scalar point. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Ci</td><td>Component number. (Any one of the Integers 1 through 6 for grid point; blank or zero for scalar points.)</td></tr><tr><td>Ai</td><td>Coefficient. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Multipoint constraint sets must be selected with Case Control command, MPC $\stackrel{\cdot}{=}$ SID.   
2.The m-set degree-of-freedom specified on this entry may not be specified on other entries that define mutually exclusive sets. The GM term is an equation marker.If PARAM,AUTOMSET,YES is on Nastran may choose internally another Gi as the actual dependent degree-of-freedom.

Defines a processor entry to be used in the SOL 600 Marc Parameter Section. It controls the use of vectorization and paralelization in the element assembly phase in Marc. Used in SOL 600 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7 8</td><td>9</td><td></td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MPROCS</td><td>[2</td><td>I3</td><td>I4</td><td>I5</td><td>[6</td><td>17</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>IRF</td><td>IFGF</td><td>IAXIS</td><td>WGHT</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Dx</td><td>Dy</td><td>Dz</td><td>X</td><td>Y</td><td>Z</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MPROCS</td><td>1</td><td>1</td><td>1</td><td>1</td><td>11</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer Meaning</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>I2</td><td>Value of Marc's 2nd processor field. Number of CPUs to use. (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>I3</td><td>Value of Marc's 3rd processor field. Optimal vector length (Defaults to 32 or 64 depending on the computer system). (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>I4</td><td>Value of Marc's 4th processor field (enter 1 if beta matrices are to be formed in parallel) (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>15</td><td>Value of Marc's 6th processor field (enter 1 to use DDM single file input). (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">I6</td><td>Value of Marc's 7th processor field -- Domain Decomposition Method. (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Enter 11 to use Metis Best (best method of 12, 13 or 14) decomposition; Default. Enter 12 to use Metis Element-Based decomposition.</td></tr><tr><td>Enter 13 to use Metis Node-Based decomposition.</td></tr><tr><td>Enter l4 to use Vector decomposition. Enter 15 to use Radial decomposition.</td></tr><tr><td>17</td><td>Enter 16 to use Angular decomposition. Value of Marc's 8th processor field. Enter O to use in-core storage for DDM single file</td></tr><tr><td>IRF</td><td>creation. Enter 1 to use out-of-core storage. (Integer; Default = 0) Island removal flag for domain decomposition. (Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>0 Do not remove islands</td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td>Attempt to remove islands</td></tr><tr><td>IFGF</td><td> Fine graph flag for domain decomposition. (Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>0 Coarse graph 1 Fine graph</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="3">IAXIS</td><td>Control of point on axis of rotation for radial/angular domain decomposition</td></tr><tr><td>0 Use centroid of the boundary box of the model</td></tr><tr><td>1 User supplied point (supply X, Y, Z below)</td></tr><tr><td>WGHT</td><td>Element coefficient weight. Controls balance between computational costs of domains, range is 0.0 to 1.0. (Default = 1.0; Use full element weight) 0.0 - Do not use element weight</td></tr><tr><td>Dx</td><td>First direction cosine of vector used for decomposition method 14, 15, or 16</td></tr><tr><td>Dy</td><td> Second direction cosine of vector used for decomposition method 14, 15, or 16</td></tr><tr><td>Dz</td><td> Third direction cosine of vector used for decomposition method 14, 15, or 16</td></tr><tr><td>X</td><td>X coordinate of point on axis</td></tr><tr><td>Y</td><td>Y coordinate of point on axis</td></tr><tr><td>Z</td><td>Z coordinate of point on axis</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. This entry should only be made for special cases when using DDM with Marc's single file parallel capability. Do not enter except for SOL 600 parallel executions.   
2. Consult the Marc documentation volumes A, B, C for more detailed descriptions of this entry.   
3.Enter onlyone of MPROCS entry in any given file.If more than one is entered, the first encountered will be used.   
4. The continuation lines may be omitted if not required.   
5. I2, I3, and I4 are no longer used and should be zero or blank.  

This entry is only used if the checks built into SOL 600 somehow fail to predict some elements which need node numbering reversed.Nastran allows clockwise as wellascounter clockwise node numbering. Marc only allows counter clockwise numbering for most elements.SOL 600 has builtin logic to check for node reversal, however there may be some instances where Marc gives an“inside out"message during increment (before any nonlinear loadshave beenapplied). This rarely happens unlessfield 7of the GRID entry is set, in which case it sometimes happens. When this happens, the user can apply this entry to instruct SOL 600 how to renumber elements which have“inside out" messages during increment zero. (If“inside out"messages occur after increment zero,this is normally due to large loads and the element has either failed or the model needs to be re-meshed).  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MREVERS</td><td>N1</td><td>M1</td><td>N2</td><td>M2</td><td>N3</td><td>M3</td><td>N4</td><td>M4</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ID1</td><td>ID2</td><td>ID3</td><td>ID4</td><td>ID5</td><td>ID6</td><td>ID7</td><td>ID8</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ID9</td><td>ID10</td><td>etc.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MREVERS</td><td></td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>500</td><td>510</td><td>520</td><td>888</td><td>889</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>950</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Describer Meaning   
Ni Node number location to be reversed. (Integer; no Default; see Remark 1.)   
Mi Paired node number location to be reversed. (Integer; no Default; see Remark 1.)   
IDi Element identification number. (Integer; no Default)  

Remarks:  

1. Example of node number locations are as follows: For 4-node quads the node number locations are 1, 2, 3, 4 For 8-node hexas the node number locations are 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7,8   
2.The $2^{\mathrm{nd}}$ and succeedinglines may be used to make it easy to enter elements with“insideout" messages in a preliminary marc.out file. The user can grep for“inside out",save the message in a file, easily edit the file to retain only the element numbers and then add these to lines 2 and subsequent of the alternate format.   
3. Up to four pairs of node locations may be reversed per entry. If additional paris are necessary, repe: the entry and its continuation lines.   
4.The example willreverse nodes locations 2 and 3 for elements 500, 510, 520, 888, 889 and 950.  

5. This entry may only be used in MD Nastran R2.1 and later versions.   
6. See PARAM,MAXIREVV for a similar option.  

Defines auxiliary data for RSSCON for use in SOL 600. Used in SOL 600 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MRSSCON</td><td>ICONV</td><td>IDB</td><td>IDP</td><td>IDM</td><td>A</td><td>J</td><td>I</td><td>E</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MRSSCON</td><td>0</td><td>5000</td><td>5000</td><td>900</td><td>20.0</td><td>200.</td><td>100.</td><td>30.0E</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="2">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">ICONV</td><td colspan="2">Flag indicating how RSSCON rigid elements will be converted in SOL 600. (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>0</td><td>Convert all RSSCON to CBEAM using values in fields 2-8</td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>Convert all RSSCON to RBE2 using 3 degrees of freedom Convert all RSSCON to RBE2 using 6 degrees of freedom</td></tr><tr><td>IDB</td><td colspan="2">Starting CBEAM ID for all RSSCON's that are mapped to CBEAM's or RBE2 ID if RSSCON's are mapped to RBE2's (Integer; Default = 99000; see Remark 1.)</td></tr><tr><td>IDP</td><td colspan="2">PBEAM ID for use by all RSSCON's in the model mapped to CBEAM's. See Remark 5. (Integer; Default = 99000)</td></tr><tr><td>IDM</td><td colspan="2">MAT1 ID for use by all RSSCON's in the model mapped to CBEAM's. See Remark 6. (Integer; Default = 99000)</td></tr><tr><td>A</td><td colspan="2">Area to be placed in the PBEAM (Real; Default = 10.0)</td></tr><tr><td>J</td><td colspan="2">Torsional moment of inertia to be placed in the PBEAM (Real; Default = 20.0)</td></tr><tr><td>I</td><td colspan="2">Moment of inertia (in both directions) to be placed in the PBEAM (Real; Default = 10.0)</td></tr><tr><td>E</td><td colspan="2">Elastic modulus to be placed in the IDM MAT1 entry (Real; Default = 1.0E6)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1．ICONV $\stackrel{\cdot}{=}1$ or 2 may cause MPC conflicts and/or may fail if AUTOMSET,YES is used.   
2. RSSCON type $\vDash$ elem is not presently supported by SOL 600.   
3. This entry applies to RSSCON type $\mathrel{\mathop:}=$ grid where ES1, EA1, EB1 all have different coordinates, and if used ES2, EA2 and EB2 do not have the same coordinates as each other (see RSSCON entry for meaning of these values).   
4. Only one MRSSCON entry should be include in the input data. If more than one is included, the first as determined by XSORT, will be used.   
5. If IDP is entered, a PBEAM with and id of IDP and properties A, J,and I will automatically be created.   
6.IfIDM is entered, a MAT1 with a Young's modulus of E and Poisson ratio ofO.3 willautomatically be created.  

Defines the direction in which 3D Solid Composites are stacked. Used in SOL 600 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MSTACK</td><td>ID1</td><td>THRU</td><td>ID2</td><td>IDIR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MSTACK</td><td>100</td><td>THRU</td><td>200</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID1</td><td>Starting solid element ID (Integer; Required; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>THRU</td><td>Enter the character string THRU if more than one element is desired</td></tr><tr><td>ID2</td><td>Ending solid element in a range of ID1 to ID2 (Integer; optional; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>IDIR</td><td>Stacking direction for this range of solid elements (Integer; Required; Default = 1)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>1 Thickness direction is 1-2-3-4 face to 5-6-7-8 face (for CHEXA)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>2 Thickness direction is 1-5-8-4 face to 2-6-7-3 face (for CHEXA)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>3 Thickness direction is 2-6-5-1 face to 3-7-8-4 face (for CHEXA)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Enter as many MSTACK lines as necessary to define any solid composites where the defaults do nol apply. If IDIR is 1 for all elements in the range, this entry is not required. 2. This entry equates to Marc's EGEOM3 value for solid composite elements (for example element 149).  

Limits elements and/orgrid results to selected elements or grids fortl6 and tl9 file results.Used in SOL 600.  

Format   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>MT16SEL</td><td>TYPE</td><td>ID1</td><td>THRU</td><td>ID2</td><td>BY</td><td>ID3</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>TYPE</td><td>ID1</td><td>THRU</td><td>ID2</td><td>BY</td><td>ID3</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MT16SEL GRID</td><td>1</td><td>THRU</td><td>100</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>GRID</td><td>2525</td><td>THRU</td><td>3000 BY</td><td>10</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>ELEM</td><td>100</td><td>THRU</td><td>500 BY</td><td>2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>ELEM</td><td>1000</td><td>THRU</td><td>2000</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td>Type of output - Enter one of the values “GRID”, or “ELEM", for“GRID”， nodal results such as displacement, spc force, etc are selected. For“ELEM", element results such as stress, strain, etc. are selected. This entry should normally be used in combination with MARCOUT unless the MARCOUT defaults are satisfactory for the</td></tr><tr><td>ID1</td><td>model. Starting ID of above selection. (Integer; no Default required value)</td></tr><tr><td>ID2</td><td>Ending ID of above selection. (Integer; Default = ID1)</td></tr><tr><td>ID3</td><td>Increment by value. (Integer; Default = 1)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. It is highly recommended that allgrid and element output be placed on the tl6 file since it is not usuall known where the maximum values willoccur and the max/min values could easily be missed. Also, if all grid/element values are not selected, contour plots could be misleading. To output all grid/element results in the tl6 file, do not make any MT16SEL entries.   
2. This entry may not be used when OUTR options (which requires a tl6 to op2 conversion) on the SOL 600 entry are requested. If this entry is made together with any OUTR options, this entry will be ignored and a warning message issued.   
3. ID2 must be blank, zero or greater than ID1 (if ID2 is blank or zero, only ID1 willbe used)   
4.ID3 must not be negative. If can be blank or zero in which case it is reset to one.   
5. This entry (with the exception of Remark 3) activates Marc's POST version 13 and overrides any other POST version specifications such as PARAM,MARCPOST.   
6.This entry can be used to also obtain a tl9 file with selected element and/or grid results by placing PARAM,MARCT19,1 in the bulk data.  

7.It is not presently possible to only create at19 file with selected element/grid results using SOL 600. If a tl9 file is desired, a tl6 file must also be created.  

Determines how to split a Marc tl6 file into one or more smaller tl6 files in SOL 600.Splitting of a large t16file is sometimes necessary if the postprocessor aborts due to the large amount of data or if the results need to be transferred to another computer for postprocessing.  

Format: This entry is available in small field format only:  

Examples:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MT16SPL</td><td>IOPT</td><td>NVECT</td><td>FNAME</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ID1</td><td>START</td><td>LAST</td><td>INCR</td><td>(remark 4)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ID2</td><td>START</td><td>LAST</td><td>INCR</td><td>LastFew</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>MT16SPL</td><td>0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>１</td><td>5</td><td>100</td><td>５</td><td>3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>MT16SPL</td><td>0</td><td>old1.mar</td><td>c.t16</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>1 10</td><td>80</td><td>10</td><td>3</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>2 90</td><td>100</td><td>5</td><td>4</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>MT16SPL</td><td>1 1</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>MT16SPL</td><td>3 1</td><td>2 10</td><td>old2.t16 100</td><td>10 3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Create several new tl6 files with 2 increments each using originalincrements 10,20,..98,99,100.This is a restart job and uses old2.tl6 (from a standalone Marc run).New files will be created as follows:  

jid.0001.tl6 with old increments 10, 20   
jid.0002.tl6 with old increments 30, 40   
jid.0003.tl6 with old increments 50, 60   
jid.0004.tl6 with old increments 70,80   
jid.0005.tl6 with old increments 90,98   
jid.0006.tl6 with old increments 99, 100  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="2">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="3">IOPT</td><td colspan="2">Option of how to split up the “old" tl6 file. (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>0</td><td>Split into as many new tl6 files as there are continuation lines of this entry, use the current jid.marc.tl6 file, FNAME should not be entered.</td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td>Split into as many new tl6 files with NVECT original increments each, use the current jid.marc.tl6 file, FNAME should not be entered.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="2">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td>2</td><td>Split into as many new tl6 files as there are continuation lines of this entry, use a previously generated tl6 file whose name is specified by FNAME.</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>Split into as many new tl6 files with NVECT original increments each, use a previously generated tl6 file whose name is specified by FNAME.</td></tr><tr><td>NVECT</td><td colspan="2">Number of increments to be placed on each new tl6 file (only used if IOPT is 1 or 3) (Integer; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>FNAME</td><td colspan="2">Original tl6 filename - Only used if IOPT is 2 or 3. (Character; no Default) The filename may extend from fields 4-9. If it is more than 8 characters long, this entry must made in fixed format. the entire tl6 filename including the tl6 extension should be entered. No upper case letters may be used. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>IDi</td><td colspan="2">New tl6 plot ID (must start with 1 and increase by 1 on each continuation line.) (Integer; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>START</td><td colspan="2">Starting Marc increment to be placed on new tl6 file. (Integer; Default = 1) Last Marc increment in range of start-last-incr to be n new tl6 file. (Integer; Default is</td></tr><tr><td>LAST</td><td colspan="2">last increment on original tl6 file if FNAME is blank. If FNAME is not blank, LAST must be an accurate value which can be obtained from the .sts file of the original run that produced FNAME.)</td></tr><tr><td>INCR</td><td colspan="2">Increments to be used for start-last-incr tgo b e on new tl6 file. (Integer; Default = 1) In addition to START,LAST,INCR the last several increments may be placed on the t16</td></tr><tr><td>Last Few</td><td colspan="2">file. In the first example increments 5, 10, 15, .., 100, 99, 98 are placed on the new t16 file. LastFew may only be entered on the last line. (Integer; Default = 2)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

# Remarks:  

<html><body><table><tr><td></td><td>1. Sometimes large SOL 600 models do not converge on a user wishes to examine output at unknown time intervals.To determine what is happening, it is frequently necessary to plot the results at several output intervals. In fact, sometimes the last increment may have bogus results due to divergence. At present, MSC GUI programs sometimes are not capable of postprocessing the large amount of data</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>or more smaller files. 2. GUl's mightonly be able to handle one increment per tl6 file for extremely large models.To specify this, only enter Id and START as in the 3rd example.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td> 3. All tl6 files will have the geometry as well as the specified output increments.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>4. LastFew may only be entered on the last line.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>5. Nastran may be restarted to perform this step. To do so, enter</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>SOL 600,ID t16split=fname Where fname is the jid of the original job.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>6. The new files will be named jid.ID.tl6. Examples are as follows:</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Case 1 - Split up tl6 as part of current run starting with jidl.dat as the Nastran input SOL 600 will create jidl.marc.tl6 with a full set of output increments (unless reduced by you).  

jid1.0001.t16 jid1.0002.t16 etc.  

Case 2 - Split up a tl6 file formed by a previous SOL 600 run named jidl.dat (the tl6 file is named jidl.marc.tl6). The current Nastran input file to split up the original tl6 is named jid2.dat. The new t16 files will be designated:  

jid2.00001.t16 jid2.00002.t16 etc.  

7. Nastran will spawn Marc's pldump2000 program to split up the original tl6 file.  

8. If FNAME is entered (IOPT $\scriptstyle\mathbf{\dot{\rho}}=2$ or 3), OUTR options (on SOL600,ID) will be ignored. If FNAME is blank and IOPT $\scriptstyle\mathbf{\bar{\rho}}=0$ or l and OUTR options are requested, the tl6op2 translator process the full (unsplit) jid.mar.tl5 file. Future implementations may allow processing of the split tl6 files.  

9. Only one MT16SPL (plus many continuation lines as necessary) is allowed per job.  

In some cases, a model is built with tables defined backwards.For example,for a stress-strain curve the compression position of the curve might really need to be the tension portionand visa versa.This entry allows them to be reversed.In addition,this entry allows auser to add apoint to the lower and/or upper end of the tables in SOL 600 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MTABRV</td><td>ID1</td><td>THRU</td><td>ID2</td><td>IREV</td><td>XLOW</td><td>YLOW</td><td>XHIGH</td><td>YHIGH</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MTABRV</td><td>1</td><td>THRU</td><td>10</td><td>1</td><td>-100.</td><td>-1.0E7</td><td>0.01</td><td>1.0E7</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>21</td><td>THRU</td><td>25</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>45</td><td>THRU</td><td>48</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>25.5</td><td>66523.</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID1</td><td>Starting table ID to be reversed. (Integer; Required; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>THRU</td><td>Enter the character string THRU if more than one grid is desired.</td></tr><tr><td>ID2</td><td>Ending table ID of the range. (Integer; or blank. If blank; ID2=ID1)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="3">IREV</td><td>Option to reverse (flip) positive and negative values and change the sign for tables in the range ID1 to ID2. (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>0 Do not reverse</td></tr><tr><td>1 Reverse</td></tr><tr><td>XLOW</td><td>Option to add a point to the lower end of these tables. If so, XNEG is the lower end X value to be added (after reversal, if IREV=1). (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>YLOW</td><td>Option to add a point to the lower end of these tables. If so, YNEG is the lower end Y value to be added (after reversal, if IREV=1). (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>XHIGH</td><td>Option to add a point to the upper end of these tables. If so, XPOS is the upper end X value to be added (after reversal, if IREV=1). (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>YHIGH</td><td>Option to add a point to the upper end of these tables. If so, YPOS is the upper end Y value to be added (after reversal, if IREV=1). (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Missing tables in the range IDl to ID2 will be ignored and no error will be produced. 2. This capability is limited to tables defined using TABLES1, TABLEDl and/or TABLEMl and the behavior in the x and y directions must be linear.  

3. Values XLOW, YLOS, XHIGH, YHIGH are not reversed and the signs are not changed even if $\mathrm{IREV}{=}1$ ·   
4.The first example reverses tables 1-10 and also adds a point at the lower and upper end. The second example reverses tables 21-25, no additional points are added.The third example adds a point to the upper end of tables 45-48, does not reverse the tables or add a point to the lower end.   
5.This entry willreverse both Xand Yof the specified tables and is not capable of reversing only Xor Y.

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Identification number of a matching Case Control NLPARM command (for statics) or entry (for dynamics). (Integer; no Default; Required field)</td></tr><tr><td>Tchg</td><td>Maximum temperature change to be used per step of the stress analysis. Remarks:

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1 NHRMPRM</td><td>2 PARAM1</td><td>3 VAL1</td><td>4 PARAM2</td><td>5 VAL2</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>NHRMPRM</td><td>MNCSF</td><td>3</td><td>NLHDIAG</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Var Name</td><td>Type/ Default</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr><td>NLHRED</td><td>I=-1</td><td>Use reduction for nonlinear analysis.</td></tr><tr><td>NHPLUS</td><td>I=20</td><td>Number of extra points to avoid aliasing.</td></tr><tr><td>NLHTOL</td><td>R = 1.0E-5</td><td>Tolerance for convergence.</td></tr><tr><td>NLHTWK</td><td>R= 1.1</td><td> Push-off factor for line search in case convergence fails.</td></tr><tr><td>MXICODEO</td><td>I=5</td><td>If solution fails to converge for mxicode0 steps, new trial displacement is used.</td></tr><tr><td>TICPNCH</td><td>[=0</td><td>If TICPNCH = -1 then write a TIC Bulk Data entry for each degree- of-freedom in the d-set to be included in a subsequent transient analysis run.</td></tr><tr><td>MNCSF</td><td>I= 1000</td><td>Max number of non-converged sequential frequencies for RESET.</td></tr><tr><td>MFRINT</td><td>R=10.</td><td> Maximum frequency interval for RESET.</td></tr><tr><td>NLHDIAG</td><td>[=0</td><td>Output additional diagnostic messages.</td></tr><tr><td>CONTP</td><td>[=0</td><td>Continuation procedure.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Following parameters can also be specified using PARAM option: NLHRED, NHPLUS, NLHTOL, NLHTWK, TICPNCH and MXICODE0. See description under PARAM for more details about these variables. In case a parameter is specified in NHRMPRM and also using PARAM, the value specified using PARAM entry is used.   
2. Parameters MNCSF or MFRINT can be used to reset initial condition in case of non-convergence. If both these parameters are specified, the condition which is satisfied first is used.   
3． $\mathrm{CONTP}=1$ is used to initiate continuation procedure method. In this case, following parameters are not used in the analysis: NLHRED, MNCSF, MFRINT. Currently, the CONTP option is available for frequency-independent analysis only. Here, NLHRED is set to O to not use the reduction method. And initial condition for the continuation procedure is determined using the results from two previously converged solutions.

6.The continuation lines may be omitted if not needed. If one of the continuation lines is needed, all proceeding continuation lines must be entered and at least one value per line is specified (no blank lines are allowed).   
7.Ifan NLAUTO field is blank for the second and following subcases, the value willbe assumed to be the same as that ofthe proceeding subcase for the same field.Ifthis is not the behavior that is desired, be sure not to leave fields blank that should vary between the current and previous subcases.   
8. Dynamics TINIT and TFINAL are determined from and TABLED1 entries. They are ignored if entered using NLAUTO.For statics, TINIT and TFINAL, if specified on NLAUTO override the values from NLPARAM.   
9. Fixed time stepping is triggered by setting NSMAX equal to the number of steps (N) and IENHAN $\scriptstyle-2$ . It may also be triggered by using bulk data PARAM,MARCITER,N.  

10. The time step is adjusted based upon:  

if X<X1 Y(calculated)/Y1   
if X1<X<X2 Y(calculated)/Y2   
if X2<X<X3 Y(calculated)/Y3   
if X3<X<X4 Y(calculated)/Y4  

where

Defines connectivity of a threedimensional nonlinear load asa function of relative deflection and velocity of a grid pair which in turn is a function of rotor speed.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>７</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>NLBSH3D</td><td>SID</td><td>GA</td><td>GB</td><td>Blank</td><td>LID-1</td><td>LID-2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Nonlinear load set identification number. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>GA</td><td>Inner grid. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>GB</td><td>Outer grid. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>LID-1</td><td>Load vs deflection group ID of a LBSH3DG (Integer > O; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>LID-2</td><td>Load vs velocity group ID of a LBSH3DG (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

# Remarks:  

1. NLBSH3D are selected with the Case Control command NONLINEAR $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ SID.  

2. In order to ensure correct results, GRID points GA and GB must satisfy the following three conditions:  

a. They must both be grid points   
b. They must be coincident   
c. They must have parallel displacement coordinate systems  

The program checks for the above conditions. Ifthey are not satisfied, the program willterminate the run with an appropriate fatal message.  

3. Multiple NLBSH3D may reference the same SID but require different GA, GB grid pairs.  

4. Multiple NLBSH3D entries may refer to the same LID independent of SID.  

5.Non-linear load is calculated as a function of relative deflection and velocity between GRID points GA and GB and as function of rotor speed. Current non-linear load $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ load (deflection (rotor speed)). Used with LBSH3DG entries to define a nonlinear load.  

6. GA and GB must have all6 DOF in D-set.Both grids should not be dependent on any RBE or MPC and must not be constrained by an SPC. The program checks for active DOFs of both the grids. If they are not satisfied, the program willterminate the run with an appropriate fatal message.  

A limited capability is available to analyze structures with a geometryandaloading varying periodically about a symmetry axis.This capability is termed Nonlinear Cyclic Symmetry.This is done by developing a special set of tying constraints on the boundaries of the“pie-sliced"segmentbeing analyzed.For more details on the type of structures that may be analyzed using this method and it's restrictions, please see the Remarks.

(N > 0)</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"></td></tr><tr><td>LinFlag</td><td colspan="2">Linearization flag to be used if a cyclic symmetric structure consists of quadratic elements. (Integer; Default = 1)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="2">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td>1</td><td>The outer boundary of the structure is described based on the corner nodes only. Multipoint constraints due to cyclic symmetry are not assigned to midside nodes. Instead, they are linearly tied to the corresponding corner nodes.</td></tr><tr><td>-1</td><td>The outer boundary of the structure is described using a quadratic field. Due to cyclic symmetry, full quadratic multipoint constraints are set up; they are assigned both to corner and midside nodes.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. A full and "pie-shaped" structure to be analyzed using nonlinear cyclic symmetry shown below  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/d39f294e-c3a1-40ea-9210-2d9b70ddcd07/c74084f59ab4568fbc0d6111c468b10b9959bc6dc2e3949c27a6dfdd5426b5a1.jpg)  

Looking at points and on this segment, the displacement vectors should fulfill:  

$$
\mathrm{\mathbf{u_{\mathrm{~B~}}^{\prime}=\mathbf{u_{A}}}}
$$  

which can also be written as:  

$$
\mathrm{\Deltau_{B}~=~\mathrm{Ru_{A}}}
$$  

where the transformation matrix R depends on the symmetry axis (which, in the example above, coincides with the global Z-axis) and the sector angle. The input for the nonlinear cyclic symmetry option consists of the direction vector of the symmetry axis, a point on the symmetry axis and the sector angle. The following items should be noted:  

a.The meshes do not need to line up on both sides of a sector (for example, see the following figure)  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/d39f294e-c3a1-40ea-9210-2d9b70ddcd07/bf80597ece216a75329b0932e08a700f410ed48a2dda656c0885e68378003d5a.jpg)  

b. Any shape of the sector sides is allowed provided that upon rotating the sector $360/\upalpha$ times about the symmetry axis over the sector angle will result in the complete model.   
c. The nonlinear cyclic symmetry option can be combined with standard contact. In this case, both sides of the cyclic symmetry sectors need to belong to the same contact body.   
d. The nonlinear cyclic symmetry option can be combined with global remeshing (not currently available).   
e. In a coupled thermo-mechanical analysis, the temperature is forced to be cyclic symmetric $(\mathrm{{TA}=\mathrm{{TB}}}$ ) (not currently available).   
f.A nodal point on the symmetry axis is automaticaly constrained in the plane perpendicular to the symmetry axis.   
g. Possible rigid body motion about the symmetry axis can be automatically suppressed.   
h. Cyclic Symmetry is valid for: ● Primarily for continuum elements.However, the presence of beams and shells is allowed, but there is not connection of shells to shells across the symmetry plane, so the shell part can, for example, be a turbine blade and the volume part is a turbine rotor. The blade is connected to the rotor and if there are 20 blades, 1/20 of the rotor is modeled plus one complete blade. · Nonlinear static analysis including remeshing as wellas coupled analysis ·Valid for all analysis involving contact ●Valid also for: eigenvalue analysis such as buckling or modal extraction, and linear transient dynamic analysis. $\cdot\cdot$ Cyclic Symmetry is invalid for pure heat transfer. ·The contact status can be viewed. Grids tied across the symmetry plane will have a value of 2.  

To prevent confusion, it must be emphasized that the cyclic symmetry feature described above is different than linear cyclic symmetry commonly used in modal analysis where physical quantities such as ${\bf x}_{\mathrm{n}}$ , displacements, forces, stresses and temperature in the n-th segment are expanded in a Fourier series with terms ofthe cycliccomponents, ${\bf u}^{\mathrm{k}}$ ,in the fundamental region, like:  

$$
\mathbf{x_{n}}=\frac{1}{\mathbf{N}}\mathbf{u}^{0}+\sqrt{\frac{2}{\mathbf{N}}}\sum_{\mathbf{k}=1}^{\mathbf{K}}\left[\mathbf{u}^{\mathbf{k},\mathbf{c}}c o s(\mathbf{n}-1)\mathbf{k}\mathbf{a}+\mathbf{u}^{\mathbf{k},\mathbf{s}}s i n(\mathbf{n}-1)\mathbf{k}\mathbf{a}\right]+\frac{\left(-1\right)^{\mathbf{n}-1}}{\sqrt{\mathbf{N}}}\mathbf{u}^{\mathbf{N}/2}
$$  

where $k$ is the harmonic order; $N$ is the total number of sectors; $\upalpha$ is the fundamental inter-sector phase shift defined as $2\pi/\mathrm{N}$ ; and $K$ is defined as:  

$$
\textbf{K}=\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{\displaystyle\frac{\mathbf{N}-1}{2}}&{\mathrm{~if}\mathbf{N}\mathrm{~is~odd}}\\ {\displaystyle\frac{\mathbf{N}-2}{2}}&{\mathrm{~if}\mathbf{N}\mathrm{~is~even}}\end{array}\right.
$$  

There are considerable savings in both computing time and data storage associated with the use of the linear cyclic symmetry concept. Assuming a finite element model with a sector size of m degrees of freedom, a real-valued cyclic symmetry approach leads, in the worst case, to one eigenvalue problem of size m and (N-1)/2 eigenvalue problems of size $2\mathrm{m}$ . A complex approach leads to N eigenvalue problems of size m; while the fullanalysis leads toa single, but very costly, eigenvalue problem of size $\ensuremath\mathrm{{Nm}}$  

Although linear cyclic symmetry can reduce the problem size greatly, it is restricted to linear analysis, and the sector must have its surface mesh on the symmetry planes to be identical on each side of the sector. The nonlinear cyclic symmetry implemented in SOL 600 can be used for nonlinear problems, such as contact, and the nodes do not need to line up on both symmetry planes of the sector.

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Identification number referenced by the NLFREQ field (field 5) of an NLHARM Bulk Data entry. (Integer > O).</td></tr><tr><td>F1</td><td>First forcing frequency in the set. (Real ≥ 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>DF</td><td>Frequency increment. See Remark 1. (Real <> 0.0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>NDF</td><td>Number of frequency increments/decrements. (Integer > 0; Default = 1)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1.If DF is positive, it defines a frequency increment.In this case, thefirst excitation frequency will be F1 with all subsequent excitations frequencies being of larger value than F1. If DF is negative, it defines a frequency decrement. In this case, the first excitation frequency willstillbe F1, but nowall subsequent excitations frequencies will be of smaller value than F1. In both cases, the initial conditions fora frequency are the response configuration at the previous excitation frequency. The initial conditions for the first frequency are zero.  

2. Only one NLFREQ or NLFREQ1 entry with the same ID is allowed.

# Remarks:  

1.Thekeyword entries may occur in any order or not at all. If a keyword entry is missing, its defaults are assumed.  

2. The material and property related keywords associated with the entry (CREEP, ASSM, TSHEAR, LRGSTRN, TEMPP and ENTHALP) are only applicable to elements associated with PAXISYM, PBARN1, PBEMN1, PRODN1, PSHLN1, PSHLN2, PSLDN1, PLCOMP, PCOMPLS, and PCOHE entries. Other keywords SPCRMPT, HEMICUBE, DEACTEL, MAPTOL) are more generally applicable. Keyword SPCRMPT applies to all SPC temperature boundary conditions, HEMICUBE applies to radiation boundary conditions and DEACTEL applies to all elements on the job.  

3. The setting of ASSUMED STRAIN in SOL 40O is automatic for the following three elements with some conditions.  

a. 4 nodes full integration Plane Stress (PLPLANE $^+$ PSHLN2 with PSTRS -- BEH4 $\B:=$ PSTRS, $\scriptstyle{\mathrm{INT}}4=\mathrm{L})$ ；   
b. 4 nodes full integration Plane Strain (PLPLANE $^+$ PSHLN2 with PSTRN -- BEH4 $:=$ PLSTRN, ${\mathrm{INT}}4{=}\mathrm{L})$ ; and   
c. 8 nodes full integration HEXA (PSOLID $^+$ PSLDN1 -- BEH8 $\O=$ SOLID, INT8=L,)  

The application conditions are summarized here.  

OFF Assumed strain always turned off.   
ASSUMED Assumed strain will be turned on manually for 3 element types (PSTRS, PSTRN, PSLDN1) under the following cases:   
a. Elastic / Elasto-Plastic materials using small strain formulation (i.e., PARAM,LGDISP,-1 / NLMOPTS,LRGSTRN,-1). This includes isotropic and non-isotropic materials.   
b. Elastic / Elasto-Plastic materials using large strain additive formulation (i.e., PARAM,LGDISP,1 / NLMOPTS,LRGSTRN,0 or 1). This includes isotropic and non-isotropic materials.  

Assumed strain flag will be turned off for all materials using the Multiplicative Formulation (NLMOPTS,LRGSTRN,2).  

Assumed Strain will be turned on automatically for 3 element types (PSTRS, PSTRN, PSLDN1) under the following cases:  

a. Isotropic Elastic materials using small strain formulation (i.e. PARAM,LGDISP,-1 / NLMOPTS,LRGSTRN,-1)   
b. Isotropic Elastic materials using large strain additive formulation (i.e., PARAM,LGDISP,1 / NLMOPTS,LRGSTRN,0 or 1) Note that this turns on Total Lagrange Formulation currently by default for the isotropic elastic materials.  

Assumed Strain will be turned off automatically for the following cases:  

a. Any material that uses Updated Lagrange in either Additive or Multiplicative Formulation   
b. Any non-isotropic material   
4. TSHEAR allows a parabolic shear distribution for the BEH4 $\left.=\right.$ DCT,INT4 $_\mathrm{:=L}$ or LRIH (shell) elements, and BEH8 or BEH20 $\mid=$ SLCOMP,INTi $_\mathrm{\mathrm{=}}\mathrm{L}$ , Q (Layered Solid) or ASTN (Layered Solid Shell) elements.

6. NLMOPTS,LRGS,valle can be used separately or in conjunction with the PARAM,LGDISP option Two separate cases can be identified:  

a. Only NLMOPTS,LRGS specified. In this case, valle $=-1$ and valle $\mathbf{\varepsilon}=0$ mean the same, i.e., no large strain flags are turned on for the applicable elements identified in remark 2. Valle $=1$ flags the additive framework and valle $=2$ flags the multiplicative framework.   
b. Both NLMOPTS,LRGS and PARAM,LGDISP,N $(\Nu>-1)$ specified. In this case, valle $=-1$ supercedes the PARAM,LGDISP option and turns off all large displacement / large strain flags for the applicable elements identified in remark 2. Also, valle $=0$ behaves the same way as valle $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ 1 (i.e., for the applicable elements, both options flag the additive framework).  

7. Definition of the radiation exchange matrix as in the MSC Nastran Thermal Users Guide, Eq. 0-15  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{\mathrm{~\boldmath~R~}=\sigma[\mathrm{A}\varepsilon-\mathrm{A}\alpha(\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{F}(\mathrm{I}-\alpha))^{-1}\mathrm{F}\varepsilon]}\end{array}
$$  

in which the reflection matrix is:  

$$
\left[\mathbf{A}-\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{a})\right]^{-1}
$$  

Note that the reflection term is costly, since it involves the factorization of a dense matrix.  

For the SOL 40o Newton's method, the previous exchange matrix multiplied by a function of the temperature is added to the stiffness.If the exchange matrix is dense, which is generally the case, the sparse stiffness matrix consequently also becomes dense,and the factorization of the stiffness matrix becomes much more expensive.  

The input options are as follows.All options with the exception of the“faccnt" option, are available in SOLs 153, 159, and 400. The“faccnt” option is only available in SOL 400:  

hemi, view, npixel, ndiv, cutoff, fraction, faccnt, factol  

where   


<html><body><table><tr><td>view</td><td>1 to flag hemicube method. Default is 0. The following options are available only if view = 1.</td></tr><tr><td>npixel</td><td>Number of pixels per quarter section, where total number of pixels = (2 : npixel)² . Default is 500.</td></tr><tr><td>ndiv</td><td>Not used, but originally intended for axisymmetry. Reserve this one for the future to do adaptive mesh refinement, with ndiv defined as the maximum allowable number of subdivisions.</td></tr><tr><td>cutoff</td><td>Factor below which viewfactors will be set to zero. This one is applied during the last viewfactor calculation. It results in a less dense exchange matrix and therefore a faster calculation of the reflection term and of the stiffness matrix factorization. Default is 0.0.</td></tr><tr><td>fraction</td><td>Factor below which radiation exchange matrix terms are not added to the stiffness matrix. For each equation in the radiation exchange matrix, the fraction is multiplied by the diagonal term, and all terms in the equation less than this value is not added to the stiffness matrix. This procedure does not affect the density of the radiation exchange matrix or the cost of calculating it, including the reflection term, but reduces the density of the stiffness matrix and the cost of factorizing the stiffness matrix. Note that the full radiation exchange matrix still is used to calculate fluxes. Default is 0.01.</td></tr><tr><td>faccnt</td><td>Set to 1 to activate explicit treatment of reflection matrix. Default is 0. In this procedure, the radiation exchange matrix is constructed to be: R = o[Aε- AαFε]</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Note that the expensive reflection term is absent. This reduced form of the radiation exchange matrix is added to the stiffness matrix. Since the reflection matrix never is calculated and factorized, the calculation of the radiation exchange matrix is significantly cheaper. Since this reduced radiation exchange matrix is less dense, the factorization of the stiffness matrix also is significantly faster.  

For the flux calculation, an iterative procedure is used based on iterating towards a solution simultaneously satisfying both Poljak equations in the MSC Nastran Thermal User's Guide,Eqs. 6-11 and 6-12, respectively.  

$$
\mathrm{A\{q\}_{e}^{I N}=\Gamma[F]\{q\}_{e}^{O U T}}
$$  

$$
\{\mathfrak{q}\}_{\mathrm{e}}^{\mathrm{OUT}}=\upsigma[\varepsilon]\{\mathfrak{u}_{\mathrm{e}}\}^{4}+[\mathrm{I}-\varepsilon]\{\mathfrak{q}\}_{\mathrm{e}}^{\mathrm{IN}}
$$  

The value of"faccnt also can be set to the maximum allowable number of iterations to be used in this procedure. If the value is set to 1, the maximum allowable number is internally set to 100. This procedure currently is available only in SOL 40O and is not available for wavelength-dependent emissivities.  

The“cutoff" and “fraction" parameters can be specified concurrently with this option.  

factol tolerance to be used on the previous iterative procedure on the Poljak equations.

In the previous table, the Secondary Property (Column 1) is automatically flagged depending on the Primary Property (Column 2) and the Primary/Secondary Materials (Column 4). The Comments column (Column 5) indicates any special conditions that are followed by the program while doing this mapping. The Unsupported Features column (Column 6) indicates the list of options on the Primary Property entry that are not supported by the Secondary Property.  

It should be noted that the Secondary Property additions offer a wide range of element formulations that primarily cater to nonlinear extension but can also serve for linear applications.By default, the PROPMAP field is set to O and maps to the fullintegration elements of the secondary property only if necessary. For a less memory intensive element, the PROPMAP field can be manually set to l and this then maps to the equivalent reduced integration element of the secondary property only if available and necessary. PROPMAP field can be manually set to 2 or 3 when secondary properties need to be tagged to allelements in the model. In this case, the special conditions given in the 5th column above are ignored and the mapping is carried out for both linear and nonlinear materials (if allowed). PROPMAP $=2$ maps to full integration elements whenever possible and $\mathrm{PROPMAP}=3$ maps to reduced integration elements whenever possible.  

a. Property mapping is considered for all possible elements (i.e., $\mathrm{PROPMAP}=0/1$ is automatically converted to $\mathrm{PROPMAP}=2/3$ for the following conditions: When IDAMP (damping scheme specified through the NLSTEP entry) $>0$ is used for static analysis.Note that the damping scheme is only available for elements with nonlinear property extensions. · When CRITTID (user criteria specified through the NLSTEP entry) and the associated TABSCTL entry refer to displacement / stress / strain criteria for all elements in the model. Note that the user criteria are only supported for elements with nonlinear property extensions.  

When a smalldisplacement analysis is flagged for thermo-mechanical coupled analysis specified through SUBSTEP or for real-time thermo-mechanical chained analysis specified through TEMP(LOAD,HSUB,HSTEP,HTIME). Note that for real-time temperatures to be transferred from the heat pass to the structural pass, all elements need to be processed in the nonlinear program flow and this is accomplished by flagging all possible elements with nonlinear property extensions. b. Property mapping is provided for elements that are associated with special procedures / flags: · Elements whose grids are specified on the VCCT Bulk Data entry. VCCT is only supported for grids of elements with nonlinear property extensions. Elements that are specified on the IPSTRN / ISTRESS commands. These are only supported for elements with nonlinear property extensions.  

It should be noted also that while the NLMOPTS,SPROPMAP option is powerful and allows a userfriendly way to map to advanced elements, it does not provide a substitute for all cases. Defaults are provided for the most common cases on the NLMOPTS,SPROPMAP entry itself. This includes PROPBEH - especially useful to distinguish between plane strain and plane stress, DIRECT - the layer thickness direction for gaskets, THICKOP - the out-of-plane thicknessfor the planar case. It should be noted that these defaults are global defaults and apply to allthe elements for which the secondary properties are added. If such defaults are not applicable (for e.g., diferent out-of-plane thicknesses), it is the user's responsibility to add individual secondary property entries.  

IPRINT can be used to get additional information on the secondary properties that have been added. Default is O in which case, there is no print-out. $\mathrm{{IPRINT}=1}$ allows the print-out in the .fO6 file, IPRINT $=2$ allows the print-out in the .pch file, IPRINT $=3$ allows print-out in both the .f06 and .pch files.

9.The valdl value in“DEACTEL"determines in which physics passthe default deactivation rules are applied.Ifvaldl is positive the deactivation rules are applied in the specified passonly and in all other passes the defaults are switched off, meaning that in those passes allelements remain active unless a DEACTEL Bulk Data input deactivates some of them.  

The default deactivation rules are summarized in the following table:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Element Types</td><td>ByDefault Deactivated inPass</td></tr><tr><td>Connector elements CWELD, CFAST, CSEAM</td><td>Thermal</td></tr><tr><td>Rigid body elements Rxxx</td><td>Thermal</td></tr><tr><td>CONMi and CMASSi elements</td><td>Thermal</td></tr><tr><td>Interface elements CIFxxx</td><td>Thermal</td></tr><tr><td>Surface elements CHBDYx</td><td>Mechanical</td></tr><tr><td> Heat convection elements CONVx</td><td>Mechanical</td></tr><tr><td>Radiation boundary elements RADBC</td><td>Mechanical</td></tr><tr><td>CDAMP4 elements originating from CMB or CMS fields in BCBODY input</td><td>Mechanical</td></tr></table></body></html>  

The default for elements of all other types is that they are active in every pass.  

10. The“ENTHALP" keyword is applicable to elements associated with the nonlinear property extensions PRODN1, PSHEARN, PSHLN1, PSLDN1 and for axisymmetric heat transfer shells specified through PAXISYM. It provides different options to form the capacitance matrix and enthalpy vector for these elements through valclu and valenl respectively.  

The valclu value allows the choice of 3 different capacitance formulations: consistent, coupled (average of consistent and lumped) and lumped. The default value of valclu ${\bf\Omega}={\bf0}$ allows the nonlinear elements to follow the same scheme as that for linear elements; lumped for rods and 3D shells, coupled for axisymmetric shells and linear hexes, pentas, tetras and consistent for quadratic hexes, pentas and tetras. Values of valclu $>0$ allow the user to pick specific capacitance formulations for all elements.  

The valenl value allows the user the choice of 2 different enthalpy vector formulations: time integration of the enthalpy at each integration point or product of the nodal temperature with the capacitance. The default value of valenl ${\bf\Omega}={\bf0}$ allows the program to pick automatically: use the time integration option for nonlinear specific heat / latent heat, use the nodal product option for linear specific heat. Values of valenl $>0$ allow the user to pick the approach. Note that for nonlinear problems, the time integration approach is more accurate.   
11. To compute the thermal loads of 3D thermal shells in a separate mechanical run, a consistent temperature distribution type must be specified in mechanical models, i.e. LINE must be defined if the thermal model has a linear temperature distribution using LINE, or QUAD must be specified for the thermal model with a quadratic temperature distribution defined by QUAD. If LINE or QUAD is specified, the program will switch the structural shell elements to advanced elements automatically by generating PSHLN1 entries internall if no PSHLN1 or PSHLN2 entries are specified in the original model.   
12. MSC NASTRAN thermal analysis does not differentiate between top and bottom faces while applying loads or boundary conditions on shell even though the top and bottom temperatures may be different through specifying TEMPP $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ LINE or QUAD.   
13. TEMPP keyword is supported in coupled analysis or in separate runs of thermal and mechanical analyses. This keyword is not supported in chained thermal and mechanical analyses.

5. ILNMSTRS and ILSHSTRS are stress tensors formed in the basic coordinate system,their principal directions are the directions of stressvector of interlaminar normal and shear stresses respectively. More precisely, the tensor components $\upsigma_{\mathrm{ij}}$ satisfy below equation:  

$({\upsigma}_{\mathrm{ij}}-\updelta_{\mathrm{ij}}{\upsigma}){\up n}_{\mathrm{j}}~=~0$   
where;   
$\mathfrak{n}_{\mathrm{j}}$ is the stress vector direction,   
$\upsigma$ is the normal of stress vector, and   
$\delta_{\mathrm{ij}}=0$ when $\mathbf{i}:=\mathbf{j}$ and $\updelta_{\mathrm{ij}}=1$ when $\dot{\mathbf{i}}=\dot{\mathbf{j}}$ ·
