Defines a uniform static pressure load applied to CQUAD4, CSHEAR, or CTRIA3 two-dimensional elements.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PLOAD2</td><td>SID</td><td>P</td><td>EID1</td><td>EID2</td><td>EID3</td><td>EID4</td><td>EID5</td><td>EID6</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>EID7</td><td>EID8</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PLOAD2</td><td>21</td><td>-3.6</td><td>4</td><td>16</td><td></td><td>2</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Alternate Format and Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PLOAD2</td><td>SID</td><td>P</td><td>EID1</td><td>“THRU”</td><td>EID2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>PLOAD2</td><td>1</td><td>30.4</td><td>16</td><td>THRU</td><td>48</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Describer Meaning  

SID Load set identification number. (Integer $>0$ ）   
P Pressure value. (Real)   
EIDi Element identification number. (Integer $\geq0$ or blank; for the“THRU" option, E $\mathrm{ID}1<\mathrm{EID}$ 2.)  

### Remarks:  

1. In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command.  

In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry.  

2. At least one positive EID must be present on each PLOAD2 entry.   
3. If the alternate form is used, all elements EID1 through EID2 must be two-dimensional.   
4. The direction of the pressure is computed according to the right-hand rule using the grid point sequence specified on the element entry. Refer to the PLOAD entry.   
5. All referenced elements must exist (closed list) for residual only runs and are not required to exist (open list) for superelement runs; and they cannot be hyperelastic for either.   
6.The follower force effects due toloads from this entry are included in the stiffnessin alllinear solution sequences that calculate a differential stiffness.The solution sequences are SOLs 103, 105,107 to 112, 115 and 116 (see also the parameter FOLLowK, 829).In addition,follower force effects are included in the force balance in the nonlinear static and nonlinear transient dynamic solution  

sequences, SOLs 106, 129,153,159, 400 and 600,if geometric nonlinear effects are turned on with PARAM,LGDISP,1.The follower force stiffness is included in the nonlinear static solution sequences (SOLs 106, 153, 400 and 600) but not in the nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences (SOLs 129 and 159).  

7. The PLOAD2 entry may not be applied to p-elements. The PLOAD4 must be used.  

Defines a pressure load on a face of a CHEXA, CPENTA, CPYRAM, CTETRA, CTRIA3, CTRIA6, CTRIAR, CQUAD4, CQUAD8, or CQUADR element. See Remark 17.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PLOAD4</td><td>SID</td><td>EID</td><td>P1</td><td>P2</td><td>P3</td><td>P4</td><td>G1</td><td>G3 or G4</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>CID</td><td>N1</td><td>N2</td><td>N3</td><td>SORL</td><td>LDIR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PLOAD4</td><td>2</td><td>1106</td><td>10.0</td><td>8.0</td><td>5.0</td><td></td><td>48</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>6</td><td>0.0</td><td>1.0</td><td>0.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Alternate Format and Example (See Remark 8.):  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PLOAD4</td><td>SID</td><td>EID1</td><td>P1</td><td>P2</td><td>P3</td><td>P4</td><td>“THRU" EID2</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>CID</td><td>N1</td><td>N2</td><td>N3</td><td>SORL</td><td>LDIR</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PLOAD4</td><td>2</td><td>1106</td><td>10.0</td><td>8.0</td><td>5.0</td><td>THRU 1143</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>6</td><td>0.0</td><td>1.0</td><td>0.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID EID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>EID1 EID2</td><td>Element identification number. (Integer > O; for the“THRU"option, EID1 < EID2)</td></tr><tr><td>P1, P2, P3, P4</td><td>Load per unit surface area (pressure) at the corners of the face of the element. (Real or blank; Default for P2, P3, and P4 is P1.)</td></tr><tr><td>G1</td><td>Identification number of a grid point connected to a corner of the face. Required data for solid elements only. (Integer > O or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>G3</td><td>Identification number of a grid point connected to a corner diagonally opposite to G1 on the same face of a CHEXA, CPENTA or CPYRAM element. Required data for quadrilateral faces of CHEXA, CPENTA and CPYRAM elements only. For CPYRAM element triangle faces, G1 and G3 are adjacent corner nodes on the quadrilateral face, and the load is applied on the triangular face which includes those grids. G3 must be omitted for a triangular surface on a CPENTA element.</td></tr><tr><td>G4</td><td>Identification number of the CTETRA grid point located at the corner; this grid point may not reside on the face being loaded. This is required data and is used for CTETRA elements only. (Integer > 0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>CID</td><td>Coordinate system identification number. See Remark 2. (Integer ≥ 0; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>N1,N2, N3</td><td>Components of vector measured in coordinate system defined by CID. Used to define the direction (but not the magnitude) of the load intensity. See Remark 2. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>SORL</td><td>The character string SURF or LINE. SURF means the surface load acting on the surface of the element and LINE means the consistent edge loads acting on the edges of the element. The default is SURF. See Remark 13.</td></tr><tr><td>LDIR</td><td>Denote the direction of the line load (SORL=LINE), character string X, Y, Z, TANG, or NORM. The default is NORM. See Remark 14.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command. In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry.   
2. The continuation entry is optional.If fields 2, 3, 4, and 5 of the continuation entry are blank, the load is assumed to be a pressure acting normal to the face. If these fields are not blank, the load acts in the direction defined in these fields. Note that if CID is a curvilinear coordinate system, the direction of loading may vary over the surface of the element. The load intensity is the load per unit of surface area, not the load per unit of area normal to the direction of loading.   
3.For the faces of solid elements,the direction of positive pressure (defaulted continuation) is inward. For triangular and quadrilateral faces, the load intensity Pl acts at grid point Gl and load intensities P2, P3,(and P4) act at the other corners in a sequence determined by applying the right-hand rule to the outward normal.   
4.For plate elements,the direction of positive pressure (defaulted continuation) is in the direction of positive normal, determined by applying the right-hand rule to the sequence ofconnected grid points. The load intensities P1, P2, P3, (and P4) act respectively at corner points G1, G2, G3,(and G4) for triangular and quadrilateral elements. (See plate connection entries.)   
5.If P2, P3, and P4 are blank fields, the load intensity is uniform and equal to P1. P4 has no meaning for a triangular face and may be left blank in this case.   
6.Equivalent grid point loads are computed by linear or bilinear interpolation ofload intensity followed by numerical integration using isoparametric shape functions.Note that a uniform load intensity will not necessarily result in equal equivalent grid point loads.   
7. G1 and G3 are ignored for CTRIA3, CTRIA6, CTRIAR, CQUAD4, CQUAD8, and CQUADR elements.   
8. The alternate format is available only for CTRIA3, CTRIA6, CTRIAR, CQUAD4, CQUAD8, and CQUADR elements. The continuation entry may be used in the alternate format.  

9.For triangular faces of CPENTA elements, G1 isan identification number ofa corner grid point that is on the face being loaded and the G3 or G4 field is left blank. For faces of CTETRA elements, G1 is an identification number of a corner grid point that is on the face being loaded and G4 is an identification number of the corner grid point that is not on the face being loaded. Since a CTETRA has only four corner points,this point G4 will be unique and different for each of thefour faces of a CTETRA element.  

10. For the CQUADR and CTRIAR element, only pressure that acts normal to the element is computed properly. Surface tractions are not resolved into moments normal to the element.  

11. Allreferenced elements must exist (closed list) for residual only runs and are not required to exist (open list) for superelement runs; and they cannot be hyperelastic for either.  

12.If fields 3 through 5 of the continuation entry are not blank, the load is assumed to have a fixed direction. If fields 2 through 5 of the continuation entry are left blank, the load is assumed to be a pressure load. In this case,follower force effects are included in the stiffnessin all linear solution sequences that calculate a differential stiffness. The solution sequences are SOLs 103, 105,107 to 112, 115 and 116 (see also the parameter FOLLowK, 829). In addition, follower force effects are included in the force balance in the nonlinear static and nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences, SOLs 106, 129,153,159, 400 and 600,if geometric nonlinear effects are turned on with PARAM,LGDISP,1.The follower force stiffnes is included in the nonlinear static solution sequences (SOLs 106, 153, 400 and 600) but not in the nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences (SOLs 129 and 159).   
13. The SORL field is ignored by all elements except QUADR and TRIAR. For QUADR or TRIAR only, if SORL $\v{r}_{\r{m}}=$ LINE, the consistent edge loads are defined by the PLOAD4 entry. P1, P2, P3 and P4 are load per unit length at the corner of the element.If all four Ps are given, then the line loads along all four edges of the elementare defined.Ifany P is blank, then the line loads foronly two edges are defined. For example,if Pl is blank, the line loads of the two edges connecting to Gl are zero.If two $\mathrm{Ps}$ are given, then the line load of the edge connecting to the two grid points is defined. If only one $\mathrm{\DeltaP}$ is given, the second P value default to the first P value.For example, P1 denotes that the line load along edge Gl and G2 has the constant value of P1.   
14. The direction of the line load (SORL $\v{r}_{\mathbf{\overline{{\Pi}}}}=$ LINE) is defined by either (CID, N1, N2, N3) or LDIR.Fatal error will be issued if both methods are given. TANG denotes that the line load is in tangential direction of the edge, pointing from G1 to G2 if the edge is connecting G1 and G2. NORM denotes that the line load is in the mean plan, normal to the edge, and pointing outward from the element. X,Y,or Z denotes the line load is in the X, Y,or Z direction ofthe element coordinate system. If both (CID, N1, n2, N3) and LDIR are blank, then the default is LDIR $\v{x}=$ NORM.   
15. For SOL 600,the SORL field may also be used by CQUAD4 and CTRIA3 in addition to CQUADR and CTRIAR.   
16.For SOL 600, the LDIR field must be blank or a fatal error willoccur.SOL 600 line loads must use the CID, N1, N2, N3 fields.   
17. For SOL 400, with large displacement (PARAM,LGDISP),higher-order 6-node triangles (CTRIA6), 8-node quadrilateral (CQUAD8), 20-node hexagonal (CHEXA), or 15-node pentahedral (CPENTA), the load is not calculated correctly. Use lower-order elements if distributed loads are required in a large displacement analysis.  

Defines a distributed load to a CBEAM3 element over entire length of the beam axis.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PLOADB3</td><td>SID</td><td>EID</td><td>CID</td><td>N1</td><td>N2</td><td>N3</td><td>TYPE</td><td>SCALE</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>P(A)</td><td>P(B)</td><td>P(C)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PLOADB3</td><td>10</td><td>1002</td><td>LOCAL</td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td><td>MOMENT</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>100.</td><td>90.</td><td>70.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="2">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td colspan="2">Load set identification number. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>EID</td><td colspan="2">CBEAM3 element identification number. (Integer > 0, Required)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">CID</td><td colspan="2">Coordinate system for load definition. (Character or Integer; Default = “BASIC")</td></tr><tr><td>“LOCAL”</td><td>Local coordinate system;</td></tr><tr><td>“ELEMENT”</td><td>Element coordinate system;</td></tr><tr><td>“BASIC”or 0</td><td>Basic coordinate system;</td></tr><tr><td>n (n>0):</td><td colspan="2">Any user-specified coordinate system identification number.</td></tr><tr><td>N1, N2, N3</td><td colspan="2">Load vector components measured in coordinate system specified by CID.(Real; at lea one Ni ≠0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td colspan="2">Type of applied load.(Character =“FORCE",“MOMENT” or“BIMOMENT"; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>SCALE</td><td colspan="2">Load vector scale factor. (Real; Default = 1.0)</td></tr><tr><td>P(j)</td><td colspan="2">Magnitudes of load at j (j=A, B and C). (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command. In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry.   
2. The load vector is defined by $\vec{P}_{j}=S C A L E\cdot P_{j}\cdot\vec{N},$ $(j=A,B,C)$ . The orientation of load $\vec{\boldsymbol{P}}$ is determined by vector $\vec{\cal N}$ and the magnitude is equal to $S C A L E{\bullet}P$ times magnitude of vector $\vec{N}$ ·  

3.The distributed load is applied over the entire length of the beam axis, along the line of the shear center.  

Defines surface traction to be used with CAXISYM, CQUADX, CTRIAX, and CTRIAX6 axisymmetric elements.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PLOADX1</td><td>SID</td><td>EID</td><td>PA</td><td>PB</td><td>GA</td><td>GB</td><td>THETA</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PLOADX1</td><td>200</td><td>35</td><td>3.5</td><td>10.5</td><td>10</td><td>30</td><td>20.</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td></td><td>200</td><td></td><td>5.</td><td>15</td><td>10</td><td>50</td><td>20:</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="7">Meaning</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td colspan="7">Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>EID</td><td colspan="7">Element identification number. (Integer > 0)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>PA</td><td colspan="7">Surface traction at grid point GA. (Real)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>PB</td><td colspan="7"> Surface traction at grid point GB. (Real; Default = PA)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>GA,GB</td><td colspan="7">Corner grid points. GA and GB are any two adjacent corner grid points of the element. (Integer > 0)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>THETA</td><td colspan="7">Angle between surface traction and inward normal to the line segment. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command. In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry.   
2. PLOADX1 is intended only for the CAXISYM, CQUADX, CTRIAX, and CTRIAX6 elements.   
3.The surface traction is assumed to vary linearly along the element side between GA and GB.   
4. The surface traction is input as force per unit area. MSC Nastran converts this traction into equivalent nodal loads by integration over the surface. For AXISYM and hyperelastic QUADX and TRIAX elements this integration is over one radian. For TRIAX6 and axisymmetric harmonic QUADX and TRIAX elements this integration is over two pi radians.   
5.THETA is measured counter-clockwise from the inward normal of the straight line between GA and GB, to the vector of the applied load, as shown in Figure 9-141,Figure 9-142,and Figure 9-143.Positive pressure is in the direction of inward normal to the line segment.  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/d39f294e-c3a1-40ea-9210-2d9b70ddcd07/42786d3f32822c6549368fe3f66abcdf5c55777b5ecb2c865ae4dc46788714df.jpg)  
Figure 9-141 Pressure Load on CTRlAX6 or CTRlAX Element  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/d39f294e-c3a1-40ea-9210-2d9b70ddcd07/8f7757d22a44ca2a0a9481844d4184e9080f9da1415d5482038708e0a3379f6d.jpg)  
Figure 9-142 Pressure Load on CQUADX Element  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/d39f294e-c3a1-40ea-9210-2d9b70ddcd07/0ae2511b72e85777e9915ddb4bd1a0fefc78e986af12056c004696e16aacdcf7.jpg)  
Figure 9-143 Pressure Load on CAXiSYM Element  

6. Axisymmetric harmonic elements may have Harmonic "N"greater than zero. For this case the "PA" and "PB" fields of the PLOADX1 entry are coeffcients of COS $\mathrm{\DeltaN^{*}}$ theta). The PLOADX1 cannot supply azimuthal tractions on axisymmetric harmonic elements.  

Defines a one-dimensional dummy element for use in plotting  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>PLOTEL</td><td>EID</td><td>G1</td><td>G2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PLOTEL</td><td>29</td><td>35</td><td>16</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Describer Meaning   
EID Element identification number. (Integer $>0$ ）   
G1,G2 Grid point identification numbers of connection points. (Integer $>0$ ${\mathrm{G}}1\neq{\mathrm{G}}2{\mathrm{}}$  

### Remarks:  

1. This element is not used in the model during any of the solution phases of a problem. It is used to simplify plotting of structures with large numbers of colinear grid points, where the plotting of each grid point along with the elements connecting them would result in a confusing plot.   
2. Element identification numbers should be unique with respect to allother element identification numbers.   
3. Only one PLOTEL element may be defined on a single entry.   
4. In superelement analysis, PLOTELs, as wellas other elements such as CBAR, CQUAD4, etc., will affect the formation of the superelement tree. The PLOTEL EIDs will also appear in the superelement map output; see the description of PARAM,SEMAPPRT in Parameters, 783.   
5. Only grid points connected by structural elements appear on structure plots. This does not include points connected only by rigid or general elements or MPCs.A plot element in parallel with elements that do not plot will cause these points to be present.  

Defines the properties ofafully nonlinear (i..,large strain and large rotation,etc.) plane strain, plane stress, or axisymmetric element. Please refer to PSHLN2.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7 8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PLPLANE</td><td>PID</td><td>MID</td><td>CID</td><td>STR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PLPLANE</td><td>203</td><td>204</td><td>-2</td><td>GRID</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Describer</td><td></td><td>Meaning</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td></td><td>Element property identification number. (Integer > 0)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td></td><td>Identification number of a MATHP entry for Nastran conventional elements, or</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>CID</td><td></td><td>MATHE and other linear or nonlinear material entries for Nastran advanced nonlinear Identification number of a coordinate system defining the plane of deformation. See</td><td>elements. (Integer > O). See Remarks 7.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">STR</td><td colspan="8">Remarks 2. and 3. (Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"></td><td>Default = “GRID")</td><td colspan="7">Location of stress and strain output. (Character: “GAUS" or “GRID",</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. PLPLANE can be referenced by a CQUAD, CQUAD4, CQUAD8, CQUADX, CTRIA3, CTRIA6, or CTRIAX entry.   
2. Plane strain hyperelastic elements must lie on the x-y plane of the CID coordinate system. Stresses and strains are output in the CID coordinate system.   
3.Axisymmetric hyperelastic elements must lie on the x-y plane of the basic coordinate system. CID may not be specified and stresses and strains are output in the basic coordinate system.   
4.Negative values of CID willindicate an axes combination for axisymmetric elements.The following table describes the value and axes. Inside one model, only one CID value is allowed.  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Axial</td><td>Radial</td><td>CID Value</td></tr><tr><td>X</td><td>Y</td><td>-2</td></tr><tr><td>X</td><td>Z</td><td>-3</td></tr><tr><td>Y</td><td>X</td><td>-4</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Axial</td><td>Radial</td><td>CID Value</td></tr><tr><td>Y</td><td>Z</td><td>-5</td></tr><tr><td>Z</td><td>X</td><td>-6</td></tr><tr><td>Z</td><td>Y</td><td>-7</td></tr></table></body></html>  

5. $\mathrm{CID}=0$ is the default value which equal to $\mathrm{CID}=-2$  

6. PLPLANE is a primary property entry. Primary property entries are grouping entities for many applications in MSC Nastran. Therefore it is highly recommended that the PLPLANE property entries have unique identification numbers with respect to all other property entries else unexpected grouping results may occur. There must be uniquenessamong PLPLANE, PAXSYMH, and PSHELL entries.   
7. When using Enhanced materials (SOL4O0), the MID field may point to additional Material entries such as a MAT1. For a fullist see the PSHLN2 entry. If a material type other than the MATHP or MATHE entry is used in solution sequences other than SOL400, wrong results willoccur. Note linear stress recovery is not available for any element using the PLPLANE.  

Defines a fully nonlinear (i.e., large strain and large rotation) hyperelastic solid element.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PLSOLID</td><td>PID</td><td>MID</td><td>STR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PLSOLID</td><td>20</td><td>21</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td>Element property identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Identification number of a MATHP entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>STR</td><td>Location of stress and strain output. (Character: “GAUS” or “GRID", Default = “GRID")</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. PLSOLID can be referenced by a CHEXA, CPENTA, or CTETRA entry.   
2. Stress and strain are output in the basic coordinate system.   
3. PLSOLID is a primary property entry. Primary property entries are grouping entities for many applications in MSC Nastran. Therefore it is highly recommended that the PLSOLID property entries have unique identification numbers with respect to all other property entries else unexpected grouping results may occur. There must be uniqueness between PSOLID, PLSOLID entries.  

## PLTSURF  

### Surface plot mesh definition  

Defines the surface plot mesh.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PLTSURF</td><td>EID GID8</td><td>GID1</td><td>GID2</td><td>GID3</td><td>GID4</td><td>GID5</td><td>GID6</td><td>GID7</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Describer Meaning   
EID Identification number of element.   
GIDi Grid identification number of structure/cavity models or trim component surface element.  

### Remarks:  

1. This element is used only to describe the surface mesh of 3D model. The connection can be 3,4,6 or 8 nodes and the connection sequence mirrors those of CTRIA3, CQUAD4, CTRIA6 and CQUAD8.   
2. PLTSURF can be utilized to describe surface mesh on ACPEMCP for trim component coupling in PEM job.   
3. For trim component, PLTSURF ID must be referenced on SET3,id,ELEM. If SET1 entry is used with PLTSURF ID, fatal error or unexpected results may be the results.   
4. PLTSURF entry can also be used to define surface mesh for structure/cavity models and it behaves similarly as PLOTEL and does not participate in analysis.  

Defines the behavior of the marker element in the EULER domain. Used in SOL 700 only.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5 6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>PMARKER</td><td>ID</td><td>TYPE</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PMARKER</td><td>7</td><td>FIXED</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Marker property ID, referred by CMARKB2 and CMARKN1 entries.(Integer > 0,</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">TYPE</td><td>Required) Behavior of the marker grid points in the Euler domain: (Character, Default = FIXED)</td></tr><tr><td>The marker will not move in the Euler domain.</td></tr><tr><td>FIXED MOVING</td><td>The marker will be moved by velocities in the Euler domain.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. The PMARKER entry willbe ignored for elements that are referring to structural grid points. These structural grid points will move with the structure and the Euler velocities do not change their velocity.   
2. $\mathrm{TYPE}=\mathrm{FIXED}$ This means that the marker is stationary through out the simulation and it is therefore not moving with the Euler velocity. If the marker grid is located outside the Eulerian domain(s), the Marker will stillbe allowed to exist.It means,however, that no variables are recorded and that the variables will appear as zero on the Time History plots.   
3． $\mathrm{TYPE}=\mathrm{MOVING}$ . The marker is moving along with the Eulerian material. When the grid point approaches a coupling surface there is no mechanism that prevents the marker from passing through the coupling surface. When this happens the marker enters an element that is covered and motion of the grid point willstop. It is alowed that the grid point moves from one Euler domain to the other through a porous hole or a coupling surface with interactive failure.  

Specifies the mass value of a scalar mass element (CMASS1 or CMASS3 entries).  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PMASS</td><td>PID1</td><td>M1</td><td>PID2</td><td>M2</td><td>PID3</td><td>M3</td><td>PID4</td><td>M4</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PMASS</td><td>7</td><td>4.29</td><td>6</td><td>13.2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Describer Meaning PIDi Property identification number. (Integer $>0$ Mi Value of scalar mass. (Real)  

### Remarks:  

1. Massvalues are defined directly on the CMASS2 and CMASS4 entries, and therefore do not require a PMASS entry.   
2. Up to four mass values may be defined by this entry.   
3.For a discussion of scalar elements,see Scalar Elements (CELASi, CMASSi, CDAMPi) (p.174) in the MSC Nastran Reference Guide.   
4. PMASS is a primary property entry. Primary property entries are grouping entities for many applications in MSC Nastran. Therefore it is highly recommended that the PMASS property entries have unique identification numbers with respect to all other property entries else unexpected grouping results may occur. There must be uniqueness between PMASS entries.  

Defines a spallation model where the minimum pressure is constant. Used in SOL 700 only.  

### Format:  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7 8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>PMINC</td><td>PID</td><td>VALUE</td><td>FVTOL</td><td>FVTOL2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PMINC</td><td>220 -370</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td>Unique PMINC number. Referenced from MATDEUL. (Integer > 0, Required)</td></tr><tr><td>VALUE</td><td>The value of the minimum pressure. (Real ≤ 0.0, Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>FVTOL</td><td>Volume cutoff tolerance. (Real > 0, 1.E-4)</td></tr><tr><td>FVTOL2</td><td> Maximum void fraction that is permissible under tension. (Real ≥ 0; Default = 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1.If the pressure in an element fall below the minimum pressure, the element spalls. The pressure anc yield stress are set to zero.  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/d39f294e-c3a1-40ea-9210-2d9b70ddcd07/be29de3f1842a421ea9425200e6e945c4515fb8a1a35564a6a04775096bd0bc2.jpg)  

2. The default for the volume cutofftolerance is 1.E-4.This value should be decreased in case of large mass increase of material without any reason.  

3.If an element spall a void is created.In order to prevent getting void fractions that are too small, a void fraction is put to zero if it is smaller than FVTOL. The default for FVTOL is 1.E-4 and works only for Eulerian elements. This value should be decreased in case of large mass increase of material without any reason. Voids can be created during transport of material, because of a material failure and by unloading.  

4.With $\mathrm{FVTOL}2=0$ , any void fraction in an element will lead to failure, and then no tensile stresses are possible.In simulations in which tensile conditions are present, it can be required to allow for tensile stresses in the presence of a smallvoid fraction not exceeding a threshold. This threshold is given by FVTOL2. A good value for $\mathrm{FVTOL2}=2*\mathrm{FVTOL}=\mathrm{e.E}\mathrm{-}4.$ FVTOL 2 is only used for Eulerian materials. FVTOL 2 should be larger than FVTOL.  

In some cases, particularly for modeling of concrete or tires,it is beneficial to add rebar or cord material to a matrix.The resulting combined material is similar to a composite but it is sometimes easier to postprocess the stresses of the rebar and matrix separately to determine failure conditions. SOL 600 only.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PMREBAI</td><td>IP</td><td>TOL</td><td>IFILE</td><td>X1</td><td>X2</td><td>X3</td><td>MICRO</td><td>FACTOR</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>IM1</td><td>POS1</td><td>AREA1</td><td>SSS1</td><td>ANG1</td><td>IPOST1</td><td>IORI1</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>IM2</td><td>POS2</td><td>AREA2</td><td>SSS2</td><td>ANG2</td><td>IPOST2</td><td>IORI2</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>IM3</td><td>POS3</td><td>AREA3</td><td>SSS3</td><td>ANG3</td><td>IPOST3</td><td>IORI3</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>IM4</td><td>POS4</td><td>AREA4</td><td>SSS4</td><td>ANG4</td><td>IPOST4</td><td>IORI4</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>IM5</td><td>POS5</td><td>AREA5</td><td>SSS5</td><td>ANG5</td><td>IPOST5</td><td>IORI5</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>“HEXA”</td><td>ID1</td><td>THRU</td><td>ID2</td><td>IHE3</td><td>THRU</td><td>IHE4</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>“HEXA”</td><td>ID5</td><td>THRU</td><td>ID6</td><td>etc.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example (two rebar layers through matrix CHEXA elements 100-120):  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PMREBAI</td><td>20</td><td>1</td><td>1.0</td><td>0.0</td><td>0.0</td><td>1</td><td>0.01</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>100</td><td>0.25</td><td>0.075</td><td>3.0</td><td>45.0</td><td>2000</td><td>１</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>101</td><td>0.275</td><td>0.050</td><td>32.0</td><td>4 -30.0 2001</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>HEXA</td><td>100</td><td>THRU</td><td>120</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>IP</td><td>Rebar property ID. (Integer, Required, no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>TOL</td><td>Exterior tolerance. A rebar grid is considered within a matrix CHEXA element if the distance between the element and the grid is smaller than the tolerance times the average edge length of the element unless the grid is actually inside another matrix CHEXA</td></tr><tr><td>IFILE</td><td>element. (Real, Default = 0.05) Option to create a file for rebar verification. (Integer, Default = O). If IFILE=l, a file</td></tr><tr><td>X1</td><td>named jid.marc_rebar.mfd will be created for use by Mentat. First direction cosine of reference axis. (Real, Required, no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>X2</td><td>Second direction cosine of reference axis. (Real, Required, no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>X3</td><td>Third direction cosine of reference axis. (Real, Required, no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>MICRO</td><td>Option to activate“micro buckling" behavior. (Integer, Default = 0) If MICRO=0 micro buckling is not activated, if MICRO=1 micro buckling is activated.</td></tr><tr><td>FACTOR</td><td>Factor to use to reduce rebar stiffness in compression if MICRO=1. (Real, Default = 0.02)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>IMi</td><td> Material identification number. (Integer, Required, no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>POSi</td><td>Relative position of rebar layer at edge 1 (pr/t) - the ratio of the distance between the reference surface and the rebar layer to the distance across the element. (Real, Required,</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>AREAi SSSi</td><td>Rebar cross sectional area. (Real, Required, no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>ANGi</td><td>Number of rebars per unit length in each layer. (Real, Required, no Default) Angle (degrees) between the rebar and the projection of the reference axis on the rebar layer plane (see the following figure). (Real, Default = 0.0, must be between -90.0 and</td></tr><tr><td>IPOSTi</td><td>90.0), see Figure 9-144. Global identification number of the rebar layer used for postprocessing. (Integer, Default</td></tr><tr><td>IORIi</td><td>= 0) Rebar layer orientation type, see Figure 9-145. (Integer, Required, no Default) 1 = Thickness direction is from the 1,2,3,4 face to the 5,6,7,8 face</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>2 = Thickness direction is from the 1,4,8,5 face to the 2,3,7,6 face 3 = Thickness direction is from the 2,1,5,6 face to the 3,4,8,7 face</td></tr><tr><td>HEXA</td><td>Enter the string HEXA to indicate the line that contains matrix CHEXA element ID's through which the rebar passes. (Character, Required)</td></tr><tr><td>ID1,ID3,etc. THRU</td><td> Starting matrix CHEXA element ID. (Integer ID1 is Required)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Enter string THRU to indicate that more than one matrix CHEXA element with these rebar properties apply.</td></tr><tr><td>ID2, ID4, etc.</td><td> Ending matrix CHEXA element ID. (Integer, ID2 is Required)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. This entry is the property entry for CMREBAI elements and makes use of Marc's REBAR and INSERT capabilities for rebar membrane element types 147 and 148. Entries CMREBAR and PMREBAR makes use of Marc's REBAR only capability and use rebar elements 23 and 146.   
2. If rebar layers i are not desired, the lines 2-5 may be omitted. The line for $\mathbf{i}{=}1$ is required.   
3. See the following two figures for a definition of ANG and IORI.   
4. Any material valid for SOL 600 may be used to define IM.   
5. For each rebar layer,the user is required to define cord material identification number,crossection are of the cords, density of the cords, and an angle (defining spatial orientation of the cords). $\upalpha$ is the angle between the cord and the projection of a predefined reference axis on the rebar layer plane as shown in the next figure.

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>POINT</td><td>ID</td><td>CP</td><td>X1</td><td>X2</td><td>X3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>POINT</td><td>12</td><td>1</td><td>1.</td><td>2.</td><td>5.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td><td>Type</td><td>Default</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Point identification number.</td><td>Integer ≥ 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>CP</td><td>Identification number of coordinate system in which the location of point is defined.</td><td>Integer ≥ 0</td><td>0</td></tr><tr><td>X1,X2,X3</td><td> Location of the point in coordinate system CP.</td><td>Real</td><td>0.0</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. POINT is used to specify additional geometric points for edges and can be used by p-version elements. There are no degrees-of-freedom assigned to a point.   
2. FEEDGE entries can refer to POINT entries.   
3. SELOC entries can refer to POINT entries in the residual or part superelements.   
4. ID of POINTs must be unique with respect to ID of GRID entries.   
5. POINT entries can be referenced on SET1/SET3 for defining arbitrary beam crossection, ABCS via PBRSECT/PBMSECT. Note that CP and X3 must be left blank for POINT entries used for ABCS.  

## Conical Shell Point  

Defines the location ofa point on an axisymmetric shellring at which loads may be applied via the FORCE or MOMENT entries and at which displacements may be requested. These points are not subject to constraints via MPCAX, SPCAX, or OMITAX entries.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>POINTAX</td><td>ID</td><td>RID</td><td>PHI</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:

1. The PORFGBG entry can be referenced from a LEAKAGE entry.   
2. When used with Euler and SIZE $\v{r}_{\mathbf{\lambda}}=$ SMALL, this entry can only be used with the single material hydrodynamic Euler solver, using an EOSGAM (ideal gas) equation of state.   
3.For SIZE $\v{r}_{\mathbf{\overline{{\Pi}}}}=$ LARGE: once gas from a GBAG enters an Eulerian domain it is treated as Eulerian material.For the single material Euler solver only one Eulerian material is present and the material number MID can be left blank. Since GBAG material is an ideal gas it is required that Eulerian material also uses an EOSGAM (ideal gas) equation of sate. When using the Multi-material solver the Material number MID has to point to one of the Eulerian materials and the equation of state of that material has to be of type EOSGAM.  

## Porous Flow Boundary  

Defines the material properties for the in-oroutflow ofan Eulerian mesh through a porous area of the couple surface. Used in SOL 700 only.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PORFLOW</td><td>FID</td><td></td><td>TYPE1</td><td>VALUE1</td><td>TYPE2</td><td>VALUE2</td><td>TYPE3</td><td>VALUE3</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>TYPE4</td><td>VALUE4</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PORFLOW 120</td><td></td><td>XVEL</td><td>100.0</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="2">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>FID</td><td colspan="2">Unique number of a PORFLOW entry. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td colspan="2"> The properties on the flow boundary. (Character, Required)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>MATERIAL</td><td> MATDEUL ID number.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>XVEL</td><td>Velocity in the x-direction.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>YVEL</td><td>Velocity in the y-direction.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ZVEL</td><td>Velocity in the z-direction.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>PRESSURE Pressure.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DENSITY</td><td>Density.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>SIE</td><td>Specific internal energy.</td></tr><tr><td>VALUEi</td><td>FLOW</td><td>The type of flow boundary required.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>METHOD</td><td>The method used for the material transport.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td colspan="2">The value of the property specified in the TYPE field. (Real or Character, Required) For TYPEi set to FLOW, the value is a character entry: either IN, OUT or BOTH, indicating that the flow boundary is defined as an inflow, outflow, or possibly an in- or outflow boundary. The default is BOTH. See Remark 4. For TYPEi set to METHOD, the value is a character entry: either VELOCITY or PRESSURE, indicating that the material transport is based on the velocity method or the pressure method. The default is VELOCITY. See Remark 4.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. Reference FID by a LEAKAGE entry.   
2. Any material properties not specifically defined have the same value as the element that the (SUB)SURFACE segment is intersecting.   
3. The SURFACE can be only a general coupling surface (see the COUPLE entry).   
4. The diferent methods used to calculate the material transport through a porous (sub)surface are described in General Coupling.   
5.METHOD $\mathbf{\sigma}=\mathbf{\sigma}$ VELOCITY is valid for all equation of state models. METHOD $\mathbf{\sigma}=\mathbf{\sigma}$ PRESSURE is valid for EOSGAM (ideal gas) in combination with the single material hydrodynamic Euler solver.   
6.Alternative methods are available to define holes and permeable sections in an air bag.Seethe entries: LEAKAGE, PORHOLE, PERMEAB, PORFGBG and PERMGBG.   
7. In the case of material flow into a multi-material Euler mesh,the material number, the density and specific energy have to be set. On the other hand when material flows out of a multi-material Euler mesh it is assumed that each of the materials present in the outflow Euler element contributes to the out flow of mass. The materials are transported in proportion to their relative volume fractions   
8. Prescribing both pressure and velocity may lead to the instabilities.  

Defines a time dependent flow trough a porous area of the couple surface. Used in SOL 700 only.

Value of specific internal energy. If SIETYPE = TABLE it refers to a TABLED1. Required</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. Reference FID by a LEAKAGE entry.   
2.Any material properties not specificaly defined have the same value as the element that the segment of the coupling surface is intersecting.   
3. The surface can be only a general coupling surface (see the COUPLE entry).   
4.Alternative methods are available to define holes and permeable sections inan air bag.See the entries: LEAKAGE, PORHOLE,PERMEAB, PORFGBG and PERMGBG.   
5. In the case of material flow into a multi-material Euler mesh,the material number,the density and specific energy have to be set. On the other hand when material flows out of a multi-material Euler mesh it is assumed that each of the materials present in the outflow Euler element contributes to the out flow of mass. The materials are transported in proportion to their relative volume fractions  

6.The boundary condition initiates/determines a wave in compressible material like gas and water. This can be either an outgoing or an ingoing wave. For stability it is important that the waves created are compatible with the flow type near the boundary. Relevant flow types are subsonic inflow, subsonic outflow, supersonic inflow and supersonic outflow. For example for subsonic inflow prescribing both pressure and velocity would initiate outgoing waves. Outgoing waves for an inflow boundary condition is known to be instable. However,for supersonic inflow one can specify both pressure and velocity since there are no outgoing waves at a supersonic inflow boundary.  

Defines a hole in a COUPLE and/or GBAG surface. Used in SOL 700 only.

See Remark 6. (Integer > 0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. The PORHOLE entry can be referenced from a LEAKAGE entry.   
2. When used with Euler,this entry can only be used with the single material hydrodynamic Euler solver, using an EOSGAM (ideal gas) equation of state.   
3. The values for the environment $p_{e n\nu}$ (PENV), $\uprho_{e n\nu}$ (RHOENV), $e_{e n\nu}$ (SIEENV) must be defined consistent with an ideal-gas equation of state: $p_{e n\nu}~=~(\gamma_{e n\nu}-1)\uprho_{e n\nu}e_{e n\nu}$ The $\upgamma_{e n\upnu}$ is calculatedand isonly usedwhen inflowoccurs.Inflowoccurs when $p_{e n\nu}>p_{i n s i d e}$ ：   
4.CP isonly required ifupdating of Euler or gasbag gas constants is done,for example ifhybrid inflators are defined.   
5. For in and out flow of an uniform pressure air bag (GBAG), the material transport is based on the theory of one-dimensional gas flow through a small orifice, and depends on the pressure diffrence. This is equivalent to the PORHOLE entry.   
6. When used in combination with the single material hydrodynamic Euler solver, an EOSGAM (ideal gas) equation of state is required. In that case, the material number, MID, can be left blank. When using the multi-material solver, the material number, MID, has to point to one of the Eulerian materials and the equation of state of that material has to be of type EOSGAM.  

Prescribes a hydrostatic pressure profile on a porous BSURF Used in SOL 700 only.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PORHYDS</td><td>PID</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PORHYDS</td><td>120</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Describer Meaning PID Unique number of a PORHYDS entry. (Integer $>0$ ; Required)  

### Remarks:  

1. Reference PID by a LEAKAGE entry.   
2. The surface can be only a general coupling surface (see the COUPLE entry).   
3.It is required that the coupling surface refers to a HYDSTAT entry.This HYDSTAT entry will be used to prescribe a hydrostatic pressure profile on the subsurface. For example, the water level and atmospheric pressure are taken from the HYDSTYAT entry.This defines the pressure and the inflow density.   
4.In contributions of the surfaceto the Euler elements the pressure gradient across the surface is taken into account. Therefore splitting up of the surface and creating new PORHYDS entries does not increase the accuracy of prescribed pressures.If the water leveland atmospheric pressure are the same in the whole region outside the coupling surface using one PORHYDS entry is sufficient.   
5.The atmospheric pressure is prescribed on those parts of the surface that are above the water level.  

Defines a porosity model of a COUPLE surface through a user-written subroutine. Use in SOL700 only.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PORUDS</td><td>PID</td><td>GROUP</td><td>UNAME</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>

(Character; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>UNAME</td><td>User subroutine name associated with the entry. (Character; default=EXPOR)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:

3. UNAME can be:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Subroutine Name</td><td>Function</td></tr><tr><td>EXPOR</td><td>Standard user defined flow boundary on the coupling</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Defines the properties and stress evaluation techniques to be used with the CRAC2D structural element.  

### Format:  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>PRAC2D</td><td>PID</td><td>MID</td><td>T</td><td>IPLANE</td><td>NSM</td><td>GAMMA</td><td>PHI</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PRAC2D</td><td>108</td><td>2</td><td>0.10</td><td>0</td><td>.17</td><td>.50</td><td>180.</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td>Property identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Material identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>T</td><td>Element thickness. (Real > 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>IPLANE</td><td>Plane strain or plane stress option. Use O for plane strain; 1 for plane stress. (Integer = 0 or 1, Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>NSM</td><td>Non-structural mass per unit area. (Real ≥ 0.0; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>GAMMA</td><td>Exponent used in the displacement field. See Remark 4. (Real; Default = 0.5)</td></tr><tr><td>PHI</td><td>Angle(in degrees) relative to the element x-axis along which stress intensity factors are to be calculated. See Remark 4. (Real; Default = 180.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. PRAC2D is a primary property entry. Primary property entries are grouping entities for many applications in Nastran. Therefore it is highly recommended that the PRAC2D property entries have unique identification numbers with respect to all other property entries else unexpected grouping results may occur. There must be uniqueness between PRAC2D entries.   
2. PRAC2D entry may refer to MAT1, MAT2, or MAT8 material property entries.   
3. For plane strain analysis, only MAT1 type data should be used.   
4. Nondefault values for GAMMA and PHI have not been tested. Therefore, the default value should be used.  

Defines the properties of the CRAC3D structural element.  

### Format:  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PRAC3D</td><td>PID</td><td>MID</td><td>GAMMA</td><td>PHI</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PRAC3D</td><td>108</td><td>2</td><td>.50</td><td>180.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td>Property identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Material identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>GAMMA</td><td>Exponent used in the displacement field. See Remark 3. (Real; Default = 0.5)</td></tr><tr><td>PHI</td><td>Angle (in degrees) relative to the element x axis along which stress intensity factors are to be calculated. See Remark 3. (Real; Default = 180.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. PRAC3D is a primary property entry. Primary property entries are grouping entities for many applications in MSC Nastran. Therefore it is highly recommended that the PRAC3D property entries have unique identification numbers with respect to all other property entries else unexpected grouping results may occur. There must be uniqueness between PRAC3D entries.   
2. Either isotropic (MAT1） or anisotropic (MAT9) material entries may be referenced.   
3. Nondefault values for GAMMA and PHI have not been tested. Therefore, the default value shoul be used.  

Defines the static pressure loading on a conical shell element.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PRESAX</td><td>SID</td><td>P</td><td>RID1</td><td>RID2</td><td>PHI1</td><td>PH12</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PRESAX</td><td>3</td><td>7.92</td><td>4</td><td>3</td><td>20.6</td><td>31.4</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>P</td><td>Pressure value. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>RID1, RID2</td><td>Ring identification numbers. See RINGAX entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>PHI1, PHI2</td><td>Azimuthal angles in degrees. (Real; PHI2 > PHI1)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. PRESAX is allowed only if an AXIC entry is also present.   
2. Load sets must be selected with the Case Control command $\mathrm{LOAD}=\mathrm{SID}$ ·   
3.Fora discussion of the conical shell problem, seeConical Shel Element(RlNGAX) (p.145) in the MSC   
Nastran Reference Guide.   
4. For axisymmetric loading over 360 degrees, use $\mathrm{PHI1}=0.0$ and $\mathrm{PHI}2=360.0$ ·  

Defines the location of pressure points in the fluid for recovery of pressure data.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PRESPT</td><td>IDF</td><td>IDP1</td><td>PHI1</td><td>IDP2</td><td>PHI2</td><td>IDP3</td><td>PHI3</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PRESPT</td><td>14</td><td>141</td><td>0.0</td><td>142</td><td>90.0</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>IDF</td><td>Fluid point (RINGFL entry) identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>IDPi</td><td> Pressure point identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>PHli</td><td>Azimuthal position on fluid point referenced by IDF in fluid coordinate system. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. PRESPT is allowed only if an AXIF entry is also present.   
2. All pressure point identification numbers must be unique with respect to other scalar, structural, and fluid points.   
3. The pressure points are used primarily for the identification ofoutput data.They may also be used as points at which to measure pressure for input to control devices.   
4. One, two, or three pressure points may be defined per entry.   
5. Output requests for velocity and acceleration of these degrees-of-freedom willresult in derivatives of pressure with respect to time.

Rod Property  

Defines the properties of a rod element (CROD entry).  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>PROD</td><td>PID</td><td>MID</td><td>A</td><td>J</td><td>C</td><td>NSM</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PROD</td><td>17</td><td>23</td><td>42.6</td><td>17.92</td><td>4.2356</td><td>0.5</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td colspan="7"></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="7">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td colspan="7"> Property identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td colspan="7"> Material identification number. See Remarks 2. and 3. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">A</td><td colspan="8">Area of the rod. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">J</td><td colspan="8">Torsional constant. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">C</td><td colspan="7">Coefficient to determine torsional stress. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">NSM</td><td colspan="7">Nonstructural mass per unit length. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. PROD is a primary property entry. Primary property entries are grouping entities for many applications in MSC Nastran. Therefore it is highly recommended that the PROD property entries have unique identification numbers with respect to all other property entries else unexpected grouping results may occur. There must be uniqueness between PROD entries.   
2. For structural problems, MID must reference a MAT1 material entry.   
3. For heat transfer problems, MID must reference a reference MAT4 or MAT5 entry.   
4. The formula used to calculate torsional stress is $\uptau\ =\ {\frac{C M_{\uptheta}}{\mathrm{J}}}$ where $M_{\uptheta}$ is the torsional moment.  

Specifies additional nonlinear properties for elements that point to a PROD entry in SOL 400.  

### Format:  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>７</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PRODN1</td><td>PID</td><td>MID</td><td></td><td></td><td>ANAL</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>“C2”</td><td>BEH2</td><td>INT2</td><td>BEH2H</td><td>INT2H</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PRODN1</td><td>22</td><td>98</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td> Property identification number of an existing PROD entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Material identification number. Remarks 7.(Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>ANAL</td><td>Analysis type. ANAL='IS' - Implicit structural elements are being referred to. ANAL=IH' - Implicit heat analysis elements are being referred to. ANAL=ISH' - Implicit structural and heat elements are being referred to. (Character Default ISH).</td></tr><tr><td>C2</td><td>Keyword indicating that items following apply to elements with two end grids. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>BEH2</td><td>Element structural behavior. See Remark 4. (Character Default ROD)</td></tr><tr><td>INT2</td><td>Integration scheme. See Remarks 4. and 5. (Character Default L)</td></tr><tr><td>BEH2H</td><td>Element heat behavior. See Remark 4. (Character Default ROD)</td></tr><tr><td>INT2H</td><td>Integration scheme. See Remarks 4. and 5. (Character Default L)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. The PID above must point to an existing PROD Bulk Data entry and is honored only in SOL 400.   
2. MID ifblank (or O) use the MID value on the PROD entry. $\mathrm{If}>0$ it will override the MID value on the PROD.   
3.The MID entry may point to the MAT1 entry.The folowing table shows associated nonlinear entries.The association is established through the material entries having the same values as the MID entry.  

Caution: The MATVE, MATVP, MATEP, and MATF entries are only associated with a CROD element if the CROD element refers to a PRODN1 entry.  

The MID entry for nonlinear heat may point to MAT4 or MAT5 entries.  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Implicit Structural Materials</td></tr><tr><td>MAT1</td></tr><tr><td>MATVE</td></tr><tr><td>MATVP</td></tr><tr><td>MATEP</td></tr><tr><td>MATF</td></tr><tr><td>MATS1</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td colspan="2">Heat Materials</td></tr><tr><td>MAT4</td><td>MAT5</td></tr></table></body></html>  

If heat analysis is being performed and the user wishes to override standard Nastran heat elements, the ANAL entry must be set to IH or ISH.   
If ISH is specified then the MAT1 and MAT4 or MAT1 and MAT5 must have the same ID. MID for structure entries must follow the uniqueness rules of the MAT1, MAT2, MAT3, MAT8, MAT9, MATORT, MATHP, MATHE, and MATG entries.   
MID for heat entries must follow the uniqueness of the MAT4 and MAT5 entries.  

4. BEH2/BEH2H refers to the nonlinear structural/heat behavior of the ROD element. An underlinec item delineates default.  

<html><body><table><tr><td colspan="5">Structural/Heat Classification of Elements</td></tr><tr><td>ElementStructural/Heat</td><td>BEH2/BEH2H CODE</td><td>Integration Code</td><td>Element Type</td><td># Nodes</td></tr><tr><td>Type Rod</td><td>ROD</td><td>L</td><td>ROD</td><td>2</td></tr></table></body></html>  

5. Integration codes in Remark 4. are:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>INTCODE</td><td>Integration Type</td></tr><tr><td>L</td><td> Linear</td></tr></table></body></html>  

6. Any J, C, or NSM value on the PROD will be ignored  

7. The structural element damping coefficient, GE, is not supported on elements which reference PRODN1.  

Defines the PSEAM property values  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7 8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>PSEAM</td><td>PID</td><td>MID</td><td>TYPE</td><td>W</td><td>T IN</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PSEAM</td><td>7</td><td>1</td><td></td><td>16.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td>Property identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Material identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td>“KEYWORD” type of Seam Weld generated. (Character; Default = LINE)</td></tr><tr><td>W</td><td>Width of the SEAM. See Remark 1. (Real > 0.)</td></tr><tr><td>T</td><td>Thickness of the SEAM. See Remark 2. (Real > 0. or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>IN</td><td>Integration scheme. See Remark 6. of PSOLID entry. (Integer O or 2; Default = 2) If IN = O, 2x2x2 reduced shear integration with bubble functions. If IN = 2, 2x2x2 reduced shear integration.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. The length of the SEAM is the distance between GS and GE. The width W of the SEAM is measured perpendicular to the length and lies in the plane of the patches Aand B (see Figure 9-148).The width is also used to find the projection of the SEAM on the two patches A and B.  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/d39f294e-c3a1-40ea-9210-2d9b70ddcd07/14abc29923196dcd436e2f1eb32918f8551a8d809e13f212fb048a55f1db9f4c.jpg)  
Figure 9-148 Dimensions of a CSEAM Element  

2.Ifleft blank,the thickness will be computed as $T=(T_{A}+T_{B})/2$ where $T_{A}$ is the thickness of patch A and $T_{B}$ is the thickness of patch B.  

3. PSEAM is a primary property entry. Primary property entries are grouping entities for many applications in MSC Nastran. Therefore it is highly recommended that the PSEAM property entries have unique identification numbers with respect to all other property entries else unexpected grouping results may occur. There must be uniqueness between PSEAM entries.  

Describes polynomial order distribution and is selected by the ADAPT Case Control command.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PSET</td><td>SID</td><td>POLY1</td><td>POLY2</td><td>POLY3</td><td>CID</td><td>SETTYP</td><td>ID</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PSET</td><td>127</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>1</td><td></td><td>12</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td><td>Type</td><td>Default</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>ID selected in the ADAPT Case Control command.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>CID</td><td>Coordinate system used to specify polynomial values in different directions. See Remark 1.</td><td>Integer ≥ 0</td><td>Remark 2.</td></tr><tr><td>POLYi</td><td>Polynomial order in 1, 2, 3 directions of the CID system.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Remark 3.</td></tr><tr><td>SETTYP</td><td>Type of set provided ("SET” or“ELID")</td><td>Character</td><td>“SET”</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>SET ID or element ID with this p-value specification.</td><td>Integer> 0</td><td>999999</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. CID facilitates the specification of the p-order in curvilinear systems.For example, when modeling : thin cylinder,the user can restrict the p-order through the thickness of allelements to be 2 or 3 without specifically checking the connectivity of each element.   
2.If the CID system is blank, the element's topology is used to establish the 1,2,3 directions. The 1 direction is from the first to the second grid of the element, the 2 direction is from the first to the fourth,and, the 3 direction is from the first to the fifth. If CID is not blank then the following algorithm willbe used to determine the p-order of each edge: a vector will be defined in the CID system from the first to the second grid of every edge. (Curvilinear systems are evaluated at the midpoint of this vector.) The p-level of each edge is now determined by the nearest integer to $p\ =\ {\sqrt{\left(n_{1}\cdot{\mathrm{POLY1}}\right)^{2}+\left(n_{2}\cdot{\mathrm{POLY2}}\right)^{2}+\left(n_{3}\cdot{\mathrm{POLY3}}\right)^{2}}}$ where $(n_{1},n_{2},n_{3})$ are the components of this unit vector in the CID system.  

3. The default value for POLY2 and POLY3 is POLY1.  

4.Any overlap of the PSET specification willresult in a warning message and the use of the PSET with the highest pi entry.  

5. Whenever $\mathrm{SETTYP}=\mathrm{^{\circ}S E T^{\circ}}$ ,a SET command must be defined in the SETS DEFINITION section of the Case Control Section.  

6. $S_{ Ḋ }\mathrm{ET}=9999999$ is a reserved set that includes all elements.  

7. Whenever there are more than one PSET entries for a given element, then:  

If CID on the PSET entries are the same, the entry with the maximum POLYi will be used.   
If CID on the PSET entries are different, a fatal message is issued.  

Defines the properties of a shear panel (CSHEAR entry).  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PSHEAR</td><td>PID</td><td>MID</td><td>T</td><td>NSM</td><td>F1</td><td>F2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PSHEAR</td><td>17</td><td>23</td><td>42.6</td><td>17.92</td><td>4.236</td><td>0.5</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td>Property identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Material identification number of a MAT1 entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>T</td><td>Thickness of shear panel. (Real ≠ 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>NSM</td><td>Nonstructural mass per unit area. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>F1</td><td>Effectiveness factor for extensional stiffness along edges 1-2 and 3-4. See Remark 2. (Real ≥ 0.0; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>F2</td><td>Effectiveness factor for extensional stiffness along edges 2-3 and 1-4. See Remark 2 (Real ≥ 0.0; Default = 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. PSHEAR is a primary property entry. Primary property entries are grouping entities for many applications in MSC Nastran. Therefore it is highly recommended that the PSHEAR property entries have unique identification numbers with respect to all other property entries else unexpected grouping results may occur. There must be uniqueness between PSHEAR entries.   
2.The efective extensionalarea is defined by means of equivalent rods on the perimeter ofthe element. $\mathrm{IfF}1\le1.01$ , the areas of the rods on edges 1-2 and 3-4 are set equal to $(\mathrm{F1}\cdot\mathrm{T}\cdot\mathrm{PA})/(\mathrm{L1}2+\mathrm{L}34)$ where PA is the panel surface area-half the vector cross product area of the diagonals-and L12, L34 are the lengths of sides 1-2 and 3-4. Thus, if $\mathrm{F}1=1.0$ , the panel is fully effective for extension in the 1-2 direction. If $\mathrm{F}1>1.01$ , the areas of the rods on edges 1-2 and 3-4 are each set equal to $0.5\cdot\mathrm{F1}\cdot\mathrm{T}^{2}$ ·  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/d39f294e-c3a1-40ea-9210-2d9b70ddcd07/6bb414958da4ffdf69e7382576b9b3e8c74e43e6cd74ed724cfea607f1e0fa2f.jpg)  
Figure 9-149 Extensional Area for Shear Panel  

Thus, if $\mathrm{F}1=30$ , the effective width of skin contributed by the panel to the flanges on edges 1-2 and 3-4 is equal to $15\mathrm{T}$ . The significance of F2 for edges 2-3 and 1-4 is similar.  

3. Poisson's ratio coupling for extensional effects is ignored.   
4. The parameter entry MDLPRM,SHEARP,GARVEY(default) selects the standard Garvey shear panel. MDLPRM,SHEARP,HARDER selects the Harder shear panel: See Remark 4. of the CSHEAR entry.  

Specifies nonlinear properties for elements that point to a PSHEAR entry in SOL 400.  

### Format:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>９</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>PSHEARN</td><td>PID</td><td>MID</td><td></td><td></td><td>ANAL</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>"C4”</td><td>BEH4</td><td>INT4</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>PSHEARN</td><td>22</td><td>18</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td> Property identification number of an existing PSHEAR entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td> Material identification number. Remark 9. (Integer ≥ O or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>ANAL</td><td>Analysis type. ANAL = ‘IS' - Implicit structural elements are being referred to. (Character: Default IS)</td></tr><tr><td>C4</td><td>Keyword indicating that two items following apply to elements with four corner grids. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>BEH4</td><td>Element structural behavior. See Remark 5. (Character Default MB)</td></tr><tr><td>INT4</td><td>Integration scheme. See Remarks 4. and 6. (Character Default L)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. The PID must point to an existing PSHEAR Bulk Data entry and is honored only in SOL 400.   
2. Only large membrane rotation is supported. Stringer effectiveness is ignored and only membrane action is considered.   
3. MID if blank (or O) use the MID value on the PSHEAR entry. $\operatorname{If}>0$ is will override the MID value on the PSHEAR.   
4. The MID entry for nonlinear structures may point to the MAT entry. The following table shows associated nonlinear entries. The association is established through the material entries having the same values as the MID entry. Caution: The MATVE, MATVP, MATEP, MATF and MATSMA entries are only associated with a CSHEAR element if the CSHEAR element refers to a PSHEARN entry.  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Implicit Structure Materials</td></tr><tr><td>MAT1</td></tr><tr><td>MATVE</td></tr><tr><td>MATVP</td></tr><tr><td>MATEP</td></tr><tr><td>MATF</td></tr><tr><td>MATS1</td></tr><tr><td>MATSMA</td></tr></table></body></html>  

5. BEH4 refers to the nonlinear structural behavior of the SHEAR element. An underlined item delineates default.  

<html><body><table><tr><td colspan="5">Structural Classification of Elements</td></tr><tr><td>Element Structural Type</td><td>BEH2/BEH2H CODE</td><td>Integration Code</td><td>Element Type</td><td>#Nodes</td></tr><tr><td>SHEAR</td><td>MB</td><td>L</td><td>SHEAR</td><td>4</td></tr></table></body></html>  

6. Integration codes in Remark 4. are:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>INT CODE</td><td>Integration Type</td></tr><tr><td>L</td><td>Linear</td></tr></table></body></html>  

7. For creep material defined through MATVP, VALC $_{,=0}$ must be set on NLMOPTS, for explicit formulation.   
8. For shape memory materials defined through MATSMA, only the thermo-mechanical model is available.   
9. The structural element damping coeffcient, GE, is not supported on elements which reference PSHEARN.  

Defines the membrane, bending, transverse shear, and coupling properties of thin shell elements.

### Remarks:  

1. PSHELL is a primary property entry. Primary properties are used to internaly group entities. Therefore it is highly recommended that PSHELL entries use unique identification numbers (PIDs) with respect to all other property entries to avoid unexpected grouping results. PSHELL, PCOMP, and PCOMPG entries must have unique PIDs. 2. The structural mas is calculated from the density using the membrane thickness and membrane material properties. If MID1 is blank, then the density is obtained from the MID2 material.  

3. The results of leaving an MIDi field blank (or $\mathrm{MID}2=-1$ )are:  

MID1 No membrane or coupling stiffness   
MID2 No bending, coupling, or transverse shear stiffness   
MID3 No transverse shear flexibility   
MID4 No bending-membrane coupling unless ZOFFS is specified on the connection entry. See Remark 6.   
$\scriptstyle\mathrm{MID}2=-1$ See Remark 12. Note: MID1 and MlD2 must be specified if the ZOFFS field is also specified on the connection entry.  

4. The continuation entry is not required.  

5. The structural damping(GE on the MATi entry) is obtained from the MIDl material. If MIDl is blank, then it is obtained from the MID2 material. If PARAM,SHLDAMP,DIFF is set or is anything other than SAME, then the structural damping $K^{4}$ matrix is computed using the GE entries on the MATi entries according to rules in the following table (Table 32).If a single PSHELL corresponds to row eight (8)of Table 32,then all PSHELLs in the model will follow the rule of row eight (8).Rows 1-7 is an attempt to maintain upward compatibility, if a user inadvertently places a SHLDAMP,DIFF in the model.  

Note: Large values of damping associated with an MID4 entry, when using PARAM,SHLDAMP,DIFF, can cause structural instability in transient dynamics.

6. The following should be considered when using MID4  

· The MID4 field should be left blank if the material properties are symmetric with respect to the middle surface of the shell. Ifthe element centerline is offset from the plane of the grid points but the material properties are symmetric, the preferred method for modeling the offset is by use of the ZOFFS field on the connection entry.Although the MID4 field may be used for this purpose, it may produce ill-conditioned stiffness matrices (negative terms on factor diagonal) if done incorrectly.   
Only one of the options MID4 or ZOFFS should be used; ifboth methods are specified the effects are cumulative. Since this is probably not what the user intends,this may results in unexpected answers.Note that the mass properties are not modified to reflect the existence of the offset when the ZOFFS and MID4 methods are used.If the weight or massproperties of an offet plate are to be used in an analysis, the RBAR method must be used to represent the offset. See Shel Elements (CTRIA3, CTRIA6,CTRIAR, CQUAD4, CQUAD8, CQUADR) (p. 123) in the MSC Nastran Reference Guide.   
The effects of MID4 are not considered in the calculation of differential stiffness.Therefore, it is recommended that MID4 be left blank in buckling analysis.  

7. This entry is referenced by the CTRIA3, CTRIA6,CTRIAR, CQUAD4, CQUAD8, and CQUADR entries via PID.  

8. For structural problems, MIDi must reference a MAT1, MAT2, or MAT8 material property entry  

9.If the transverse shear material MID3 or the membrane-bending coupling term MID4 references a MAT2 entry, then G33 must be zero. If MID3 references a MAT8 entry, then G1Z and G2Z must not be zero.   
10. For heat transfer problems, MIDi must reference a MAT4 or MAT5 material property entry.   
11. The default for Zl is -T/2, and for Z2 is $+\mathrm{T}/2$ . T is the local plate thickness defined either by T on this entry or by membrane thicknesses at connected grid points, if they are input on connection entries.   
12. For plane strain analysis, set $\scriptstyle\mathrm{MID}2=-1$ and set MID1 to reference a MAT1 entry. In-plane loads applied to plain strain elements are interpreted as line-loads with a value equal to the load divided by the thickness. Thus, if a thickness of $^{\mathfrak{a}}1.0^{\mathfrak{n}}$ is used, the value of the line-load equals the load value. Pressure can be approximated with multiple line loads where the pressure value equals the line-load divided by the length between the loads. For SOL 6O0, plain strain models must be in the basic coordinate system X-Y plane.   
13.For a material nonlinear property, MIDl must reference a MATS1 entry and be the same as MID2. unless a plane strain $\begin{array}{r}{(\mathrm{MID}2=-1\$ )formulation is desired. Also, MID3 cannot reference a MATS1 entry.   
14.Iftransverse shear flexibility is specified fora model with curved shells wheretheloading is dominated by twist and shell normals are turned off (e.g., PARAM,SNORM,-1), then results may be inaccurate and may diverge when the mesh is refined. PARAM,SNORM should be set for this unique model condition.   
15.For 3D contact analysis, MID2 must be non-zero and for 2D contact analysis, MIDl must be nonzero.
